column7: Digər yazılarım üçün - https://niftiyevibrahim.blogspot.com/Bir yay axşamı Amstredamın elit restoranlarının birində görüşən iki ailə. Ləziz yeməklərin və yemək ləvazimatlarının zərif cingilti sədaları altında bayramların mənasızlığı və işləməyin banallığı haqqında söhbətlər gedir. Əslində isə deyilən hər bir boş söz və saxta təbəssümlər dəhşətli münaqişəni maskalayır. Hər iki ailənin də 15 yaşı oğlu var. Bu oğlanlar dəhşətli bir iş görərək video kameraya çəkmiş və beləliklə də özlərini və ailələrini təhlükə altına atmışlar. Bütün bunlar sadə bir nahar ərzində üzə çıxır, lakin ailələr öz sevdiklərini necə müdafiə edəcəklərini də yaxşı bacarırlar. Hətta bunun üçün bir-birilərinə zərər vurmalı olsalar belə..."Nahar" çox yaxşı süjet xəttinə malik olan və elə yaxşı bir nahar kimi ləziz romandır. Bəyənmədiyim cəhətləri haqqında sonra danışacam, hal-hazırda isə bəzi əsas xüsusiyyətləri və şəxsən mənim hansı səbəbdən xoşuma gəldiyini qeyd edəcəm. Serj və Pol qardaşları öz ailələri ilə birlikdə möhtəşəm restoranların birində görüşürlər ki, oğlanları Rik və Mişelin düşdüyü çətin vəziyyəti müzakirə etsinlər. Halbuki, bu müzakirə uşaqların problemlərini həll etməkdən savayı həm də Serjlə Polun arasında olan soyuq ixtilafı alışdırır və bir çox həqiqətləri işıq üzünə çıxarır. Serj Hollandiyanın yeni baş naziri olmağa çalışan siyasi fiqurdur, Pol isə işsiz qalmış keçmiş orta məktəb müəllimidir. Digər tərəfdən Serj və Pol qarşıdurmasında Pol üsyankar birisidir. Burda xəfif ədəbi metafora ilə də qarşılaşırıq: siyasiləşmiş qardaşa qarşı öz etirazını bildirən digər qardaş. Maraqlar toqquşması və subyektiv həqiqətlərin mübarizəsi və s.Ümumiyyətlə düşünürəm ki, bəzi kitabların ağır ədəbi atmosferini qovmaq, ədəbi stressi və depresiyanı azaltmaq baxımından belə romanların əhəmiyyəti heç də az deyil. Vaxtilə Emi Homsun "Bu kitab həyatınızı xilas edəcək", Elif Şəfəqin "Ərəf" və "Bit Palas" kimi romanlarını məni oxumağa vadar edən məhz qeyd etdiyim kimi, müəyyən kiçik və özünəməxsus bədii istirahətin təşkil edilməsi olub. Belə kitablar əgər axıcılıq və təhkiyə baxımından çox şey söz verə bilirsə, əsas məqsədə çatmaqda böyük işlər görüldüyünü demək olar. İndiki halda "Nahar" çox gözəl təhkiyə tərzinə, maraqlı obrazlara və yaxşı zaman-məkan balansına malik olan populyar ədəbiyyat nümunəsidir. Real dünya ilə uzlaşma baxımından da romanı uğurlu hesab etmək olar. Yazıçı əsas obrazların zəifliklərini və eqozimini təsvir etməkdə uğurlu nəticələr əldə edib. Müəyyən fəlsəfi mövzuların müxtəlif obrazların dili ilə təhlil edilməsi, sosial problemlərin işıqlandırılması və ədalətsizlik haqqında deyilənlər kitabın müəyyən əxlaqi ismarıclar ötürdüyünü sübut edir və bunu edərkən maraqlı format vasitəsi ilə reallaşdırır. Bu format getdikcə qaranlıqlaşan tunelə bənzədilə bilər və romanda hər şey sadə və birbaşa, düz oxucunun üzünə deyilir. Sadəcə yazıçını üçün mövcud olan müəyyən zaman və məkan məhdudiyyəti, nahardan qeyri səhnələrin xatirələrin nəqli formasından yazılmasını labüd edib. Maraqlıdır ki, bu məqam olduqca balanslı alınıb və bəzən oxucu oxuduqlarının obrazların xatirələrinin olduğunu, yoxsa cari anda baş verdiyini unuda bilər. Səhnədən səhnəyə keçidlər bədii ədəbiyyatın ən meydan oxuyan maneəsi olsa da, "Nahar" bu baxımdan sınaqdan uğurla çıxıb. Əlbəttə ki, romanın obyektiv təhlili bizə həm də onun müəyyən mənfilərə sahib olduğunu və bəzi hallarda da bədii ədəbiyyat prinsiplərindən kənaraçıxmalarının varlığını göstərir. Müəyyən ümumi səhvlər sırasına məntiqi səhvləri, tərbiyəvi nəticələrin yoxluğu, bir çox bədii ədəbiyyat nümunəsinə xas olan tənqidin olmaması və səbəb-nəticə əlaqələrində olan zəif münasibətləri göstərmək olar. Bütün bu məqamlar yazıçının şəxsi ustalıq dərəcəsi ilə əlaqədar olan bir şeydir. Məsələn, biz bütün roman boyu valideynlərin övladlarını elə öz əməllərindən qorumaq cəhdlərini görürük. Bunu edərkən onlar heç bir tərbiyə prinsiplərini əsas almırlar. Onları hərəkətə gətirən yeganə stimul onların öz şəxsi eqoizmləri və maraqlarıdır. Halbuki, əslində tamam başqa dəyərlər çərçivəsində hərəkət etməli olduqları təsvir olunsa idi, daha maraqlı olardı. Yenə də bu mövcud olan milyonlarla davranış və qərarlardan birinin seçilərək dominantlaşdırılmasının təminidir və yazıçının özünəməxsus fikir ifadəsini əks etdirir. Hətta belə olan halda belə oxucu bu səhnələri izləyib müəyyən tərbiyəvi nəticə çıxara biləcək. Kitabda baş verən bəzi hadisələrin qınanmaması ola bilər bir ölkə kimi Hollandiyanın sahib olduğu və dəyər verdiyi prinsip və qayda-qanunları əks etdirir. Azadlıq və günahsızlıq kimi anlayışlara belə alternativ yanaşmaların formalaşdırılması cəmiyyət üçün gələcəkdə baha başa gələn bir şey ola bilər. Ehtiyatlı olmaq lazımdır desək də, görünür, Herman Kox yenilik etməyərək, sadəcə öz cəmiyyətinin əxlaqi-mənəvi dəyərlərini bütün dünyaya əks etdirib. Obrazların öz motivləri ilə əlaqə yarada bilməməsi və müəyyən abstrakt məqamlar, qeyd olunanlarla əlaqədar ola bilər. Yazıçının müəyyən manipulyasiyalar edərək hər şeyi daha da qəhrəmancasına etməsi bəzən obrazların mübaliğəli və qeyri-real davranışlarını və əsassız hərəkətlərini yaradıb. Absurd məqamlar əslində artıq müasir oxucular üçün yenilik olmamalıdır, amma onların varlığı bəzi oxucuları narahat edə bilər. Fərqi yoxdur, istər obrazlar arasında olsun, istərsə də romanın fundamental prinsipləri arasında, yazıçı tərəfindən ədəbi və məntiqi ziddiyətlərin yaradılması ani olaraq parlayan təhkiyəni formalaşdırır. Yazıçı belə məqamlarla ümid edir ki, o, nə isə daha ciddi və maraqlı, həyəcanverici yazı nümunəsinə imza atır. Obrazlarla birlikdə hərəkət etdikdə mən bəzən darıxırdım və bəzən də özümü çox narahat hiss edirdim. Hər nə qədər yuxarıda da qeyd etdiyim kimi romanı ədəbi istirahət məqsədi ilə oxusam da və müəyyən mənada və dərəcədə buna nail olsam da, yenə də hərdən hiss edirdim ki, mən qəribə boşluğa düşürəm. Buna baxmayaraq, çalışdım ki, romandan zövq ala bilim. Kitabın müəyyən yenilik xarakteri oldu. Bundan sonra isə populyar ədəbiyyatın daha yaxşı nümunələrini axtarıb tapmağa çalışacam.

Jenis cerita yang awalnya tampak ibarat sebuah apel biasa, sebelum perlahan-lahan kulitnya terkupas dan menunjukkan isi yang sudah teramat busuk…Jujur, saya tidak begitu menikmati membaca buku ini. Dua bintang yang saya berikan itu pun adalah pembulatan ke atas dari satu setengah bintang, karena paling tidak, saya masih suka struktur narasi dan ide konfliknya. Ada rangkaian twist dan pembeberan informasi secara cerdik, sehingga pembaca jadi penasaran ingin mengetahui apa yang sebenarnya sudah terjadi dan bagaimana penyelesaiannya. Tapi eksekusinya menyebalkan.Saya paham kenapa gaya penuturannya (dari sudut pandang sang tokoh utama) harus dibuat seperti ini, tapi saya juga dibuat jemu oleh penokohan yang kian lama terasa kian memuakkan. Yang paling penting, saya benar-benar tidak suka cara penulisnya menjelaskan kesablengan tokoh-tokoh tertentu dan berbagai hal aneh yang terjadi sepanjang narasi melalui....(view spoiler)[.....plot device berupa semacam penyakit mental. Oke, jadi alasan itu memang praktis untuk menjelaskan kenapa berbagai tokoh berkelakuan seperti sosiopat/manusia amoral. Tidak bisa dipungkiri pula bahwa bisa saja di dunia nyata ada orang-orang seperti tokoh utama, istrinya, dan anaknya. Namun, konfliknya jadi kurang menarik. Dilema moral 'sampai sejauh apa orangtua akan melindungi anaknya' dan sifat dasar keegoisan manusia rasanya akan jadi lebih mengena tanpa harus bawa-bawa faktor penyakit mental.Sebab, faktor itu menghilangkan titik hubung ke pembaca, sehingga alih-alih pikiran "wah, bagaimana ya kalau saya ada di posisi yang sama? Bisa saja saya juga melakukan hal yang mengerikan itu...", jadinya lebih ke "wah orang sakit mental itu seram ya...." Saya pun jadi lebih malas mendalami psikologi dan tindak-tanduk para tokohnya, karena semua hal seakan bisa saja dijelaskan/dijustifikasi dengan alasan yang sama: "Kenapa dia reaksinya begini?? Oh iya... kan dia 'sakit'."Bukan berarti faktor penyakit/abnormalitas mental tidak boleh ada sama sekali, tapi saya lebih suka kalau disampaikannya secara implisit saja, atau tidak seeksplisit ini.  (hide spoiler)] Satu hal lagi: buku ini digadang-gadang sebagai "Gone Girl versi Eropa" dalam rangka pancingan demi pemasaran. Nah, saya benar-benar tidak menganjurkan penikmat Gone Girl membeli buku ini hanya atas dasar pernyataan itu, karena kemiripannya sebatas tema besar 'keluarga disfungsional' dan bagian saat (view spoiler)[tokoh protagonisnya tidak mendapat hukuman/konsekuensi atas tindak kriminal mereka hingga akhir cerita. Hal ini juga mirip dengan beberapa konsep film Woody Allen, seperti Match Point (*yang terang-terangan disinggung oleh para tokoh dalam buku ini). Dari segi gaya narasi dan tingkah polah tokoh utama, saya merasa buku ini paling mendekati American Psycho versi Eropa... suatu eksplorasi ruang gelap dan (a)moralitas seorang pria narsis bin obsesif yang hobi sekali meracau tentang berbagai hal-hal tidak penting. Jadi, anggaplah ini European Psycho, haha. (*patut dicatat bahwa menurut saya, eksekusi di sini lebih lemah ketimbang semua judul tersebut) (hide spoiler)]Pokoknya, ini buku yang cukup membuat saya penasaran, sesekali ngakak oleh kenyinyiran tokoh utama di awal cerita, dan menggumam "whoa...!" oleh beberapa adegan mengejutkan. Namun, sebatas itu saja.

Sesuai dengan judulnya, The Dinner memberikan nuansa makan malam yang mencekam. Dengan pembicaraan yang saling menyindir, Paul dan Serge pun saling serang. Mulai dari film yang baru mereka tonton hingga pembicaraan tentang anak-anak mereka. Buku ini sedikit mengingatkan saya dengan The Silent Wife, dimana cerita dan gaya bahasanya yang lambat serta bertele-tele. Dari segi kover, sebenarnya cukup menggambarkan isi ceritanya. Dengan gambar peralatan makan, seperti sendok, garpu, dan pisau serta latar berwarna hitam sudah sangat pas. Akan tetapi, sayang sekali gambar dua buah pion catur sedikit mengurangi estetika. Bercerita tentang kakak-beradik, yaitu Serge dan Paul yang memiliki anak bernama Rick dan Michel. Mereka sepakat untuk bertemu dan membahas kasus yang menimpa anak-anak mereka. Michel dan Rick secara tidak sengaja membunuh seorang wanita gelandangan. Serge yang merupakan calon Perdana Menteri, memutuskan untuk mengundurkan diri dan membongkar rahasia anaknya yang telah membunuh seseorang. Di satu sisi Paul merasa senang, karena kakaknya akan mundur sebagai calon Perdana Menteri, tapi di sisi lain, Paul juga merasa khawatir akan masa depan anaknya. Tokoh-tokoh yang terdapat di dalam buku ini tidak terlalu banyak. Tokoh utamanya adalah Paul yang sangat mencintai istrinya, Claire, dan anaknya, Michel, tapi memiliki 'masalah' di masa lalunya. Claire, istri Paul, merupakan seorang ibu yang sangat menyayangi anaknya dan rela melakukan apa pun untuk melindungi anaknya, Michel. Serge, calon Perdana Menteri, yang selalu menjaga image-nya. Terakhir ada Babette, istri Serge, seorang wanita berkelas yang ingin suaminya menjadi seorang Perdana Menteri. Selain itu ada juga tokoh-tokoh lainnya, seperti Michel, Rick, dan Beau. Alur ceritanya sangat lambat dan bertele-tele, karena terlalu banyak menggambarkan isi pikiran si tokoh utama. Alurnya sendiri menggunakan alur maju-mundur, yang menceritakan masa kini dan masa lalu tokoh utamanya. Cerita dimulai dari perjalanan Paul dan Claire menuju restoran untuk makan malam bersama Serge dan Babette hingga rencana Paul dan Claire untuk menghentikan niat Serge. Gaya bahasa yang digunakan rumit dan bertele-tele. Dengan narasi yang menjelaskan pemikiran-pemikiran tokoh utamanya, yang mungkin akab membuat sebagian pembaca merasa bosan. Sudut pandang yang digunakan adalah sudut pandang orang pertama, melalui tokoh Paul. Secara keseluruhan The Dinner cukup berhasil menghadirkan nuansa psychological thriller yang mencekam. Akan tetapi, sedikit disayangkan ceritanya berjalan dengan sangat lambat dan tidak terlalu kuat. Saya sendiri kurang begitu setuju jika novel ini disebut sebagai 'Gone Girl' versi Eropa, karena masih sangat jauh jika dibandingkan dengan Gone Girl. Namun untuk pembaca yang menyukai psychological thriller mungkin akan menyukai novel ini.Selengkapnya : https://www.facebook.com/notes/fahri-...

Belakangan memang saya sedang terlalu banyak baca dan nonton thriller, hingga sampai di satu titik yang membuatku jadi kurang asyik kalau thrillernya nggak spesial. Sebenarnya suka premisnya novel ini, apalagi thriller-nya tidak biasa. Tapi entah karena dibaca ketika sedang terlalu banyak berhubungan dengan thriller, makanya merasa kurang gitu. Tapi mungkin bila ada waktu akan diulangi lagi pembacaannya...

Resensi LengkapnyaPremisnya menarik. Itu yang membuat aku memutuskan untuk membaca buku ini. Bukan, bukan karena label "Gone Girl versi Eropa" yang ada di sampul bukunya. Misteri atas keluarga masing-masing memang menyeret kita kepada rasa untuk menyelesaikan segera. Ada aura bahwa kasus ini tidak sesederhana kelihatannya.Sayang, bukannya seperti Gone Girl yang "gelap" dan memiliki akhir mengagetkan plus menjengkelkan, semakin ke belakang, buku ini malah menjadi semakin drama. Bukan membuat bulu kuduk berdiri, melainkan malah membuat bosan. Bahkan aku memutuskan untuk baca cepat saja, karena detil yang aku rasa tidak begitu penting. Ketimbang disandingkan dengan Gilian Flynn, Herman Koch lebih cocok apabila dianggap seperti Paula Hawkins.

Setelah membaca novel ini, saya teringat ‘Holy Mother’. Orangtua yang melindungi anaknya tanpa perlu memperhatikan norma yang berlaku dalam kehidupan. Jenis cerita yang membuat kehadiran detektif dan polisi tidak berguna. Ahah. Menarik, sekaligus meninggalkan rasa ‘campur aduk’ setelah selesai membacanya. Nah selanjutnya mari kita bahas hal-hal yang tidak disukai pembaca. :D‘The dinner’ ini mempunyai tiga bagian, seperti jamuan di sebuah restoran mahal. Ada sesi pembuka, inti, dan penutup. Secara keseluruhan cerita berpusat pada sebuah acara makan malam antara dua pasang suami isteri yang hendak membicarakan aib anak mereka. Sayangnya paparan selama makan malam tidak secepat bila kita sedang makan malam di dunia nyata. Yang membuat lama adalah beratnya mencerna apa yang dipikirkan oleh Paul; sang narator. Tidak sedikit kilas balik peristiwa mendukung apa yang menjadi bahan berpikirnya. Bayangkan.. seberapa massive-nya flashback dan proses berpikir Paul akan sesuatu selama ‘The Dinner’ berlangsung dalam dua atau tiga jam – andaikan sebuah jamuan dengan percakapan itu memakan waktu yang begitu lama - sedangkan saya sebagai pembaca memerlukan waktu jeda beberapa hari untuk mencerna apa yang selama ini Paul pikirkan. Mungkin inilah yang menyebabkan beberapa pembaca tidak menyukai novel ini. Apalagi kalau novel ini dibaca sekali duduk. :DSelain paparan yang menyebabkan pembaca bosan, ada kejadian yang menyudutkan satu karakter yang berbeda kewarganegaraan dengan para tokoh utama. Andai penulis mengambil satu karakter dari ras yang sama dengan karakter-karakter yang lain, mungkin novel ini akan lebih disukai. Ini adalah poin kedua yang tidak disukai sebagian pembaca. Rasist. Terakhir, hal yang kurang disukai pembaca adalah tidak adanya karakter yang pantas untuk disukai. Untuk bagian ini, saya tidak sependapat. Terlepas dari bagaimana tiap karakter tidak berlaku sesuai harapan sebagian pembaca – yang berbuat baik, panutan masyarakat, bersandar pada pihak berwenang, dsb – saya tetap bersimpati kepada Paul dan Claire. Terutama Claire, seorang ibu yang tetap menyayangi suami dan anaknya yang berbeda dari kebanyakan.Melihat usia penulis yang tidak muda, apapun bisa terjadi. Apalagi novel ini berlabel bestseller. Katakanlah saya bukan penggemar fanatik bestseller, tapi saya tetap meyakini ada sebagian tertentu pembaca yang menyatakan novel ini bagus. Bisa saja penulis tidak sekedar menggabung-gabungkan karakter ciptaannya dalam cerita, tapi memang berupaya menyampaikan pesan tersembunyi di dalamnya. Salah satunya adalah ulasan tentang bagaimana masyarakat Belanda – negara asal penulis novel ini – terhadap sebagian masyarakat dunia tersaji dalam novel ini. Warga Belanda tidak terlalu di terima oleh masyarakat Prancis di suatu daerah tertentu dapat kita baca mulai dari bab 12. Bila ini memang benar adanya, tak menutup kemungkinan bahwa sikap-sikap yang tak menyenangkan dalam cerita merupakan wujud sindiran penulis terhadap rekan sebangsanya.

"Gone Girl versi Eropa." kata Wall Street Journal yang dikutip pada sampulnya. Blurbnya menarik banget bagian atasnya yakni MENU yang dibagi menjadi 4 tahap dari Minuman Pembuka sampai Hidangan Penutup. Sayang di bagian bawah tetap ada penjelasan detail tentang isi ceritanya. Padahal cukup bagian atas itu sudah bikin penasaran. Paul Lohman (dan istrinya, Claire) makan malam bersama kakaknya, Serge Lohman (bersama istrinya, Babette). Paul ini pria biasa, sementara Serge adalah politisi yang sedang naik daun. Lokasi makan malamnya sebuah restoran mewah yang harga makanan/minumannya tak masuk akal dan daftar tunggunya saja sampai tiga bulan. Tapi tentu saja kalau Serge yang memesan, satu hari sebelumnya pun bisa dapat meja. Pada sepanjang malam itulah terkuak sedikit demi sedikit ceritanya. Alasan mereka makan malam bersama, latar belakang kedua keluarga dan kualitas hubungan mereka, sampai pada kilas balik tentang hal-hal mengejutkan yang mustahil terjadi pada keluarga yang tampak "bahagia" seperti mereka. Semakin jauh mendekati akhir semakin mengagetkan fakta yang terkuak (apalagi kejadian yang ada pada akhir acara makan malam itu, gubrak!). Menariknya, ini thriller pertama dari penulis Belanda yang kubaca. Lalu isu yang diangkat menurutku unik karena terkait keluarga. Yang aku kurang suka cuma gaya narasi si tokoh Paul ini yang dibuat sering gamau nyebutin sesuatu, misal "Aku tidak akan memberi tahu ke restoran mana karena selanjutnya akan banyak orang datang untuk melihat apakah kami berada di sana." Atau hal 234, "Aku tidak akan menceritakan yang diderita Claire, tidak di sini, aku menganggapnya masalah pribadi." Diih .. Lalu, "Aku tidak akan menyebutkan nama rumah sakit tempat Claire dirawat." Hihihi. Oke deeh ... Aku tetap suka buku ini karena gaya penceritaannya yang tidak biasa dan pengetahuan-pengetahuan soal makanan dan minuman yang aneh-aneh. Meski demikian, aku ga sepakat dengan endorsement yang kukutip di awal. Soalnya, Gone Girl itu lebih sadis dan berdarah-darah.

Ini kovernya bagus; bikin tertarik baca. Dan, blurb di belakang buku ini melakukan tugasnya dengan baik (bikin aku penasaran, sehingga pada akhirnya aku beli ini).Ini buku yang setelah selesai kubaca membuatku sedikit banyak merenungkan soal manusia. Pikiran itu tak hilang-hilang beberapa hari setelah menyelesaikan buku ini. Bagaimana kita sangat (iya, sangat) pandai berpura-pura. Aku, kamu, mereka, setidaknya pernah mengenakan topeng dalam hidup ini. Dan mereka yang ada di dalam buku ini, sangat lihai menyembunyikan wajah asli mereka dibalik topeng. Semua kepura-puraan itu. Semua moral dan etika yang dipakai di atas meja makan. Bagaimana mungkin mereka masih bisa bersikap seperti manusia pada umumnya yang beretika di atas meja makan, dengan semua perbuatan "itu" yang sudah mereka lakukan. Aku sampai dibuat merinding membayangkannya. Apakah mereka benar-benar bersikap seakan-akan tidak ada yang salah dalam hidup mereka? Apa tidak ada perasaan bersalah sama sekali? Topeng seperti apa yang mereka kenakan sampai-sampai mereka bisa setenang itu makan di atas meja makan dan menikmati hidangan-hidangan yang tersaji. Di mana perasaan mereka sebagai.... Begitulah. *jadi terbawa emosi**tarik napas dalam-dalam*Aku tidak menyangka aku terhanyut cukup dalam pada buku ini. Padahal aku tidak punya ekspektasi yang terlalu berlebihan :") Aku membeli buku ini hanya karena : (1) harganya yang diobral (2) kovernya bagus (3) blurb-nya menarik. Tapi ternyata buku ini menawarkan hal-hal lebih dari itu. Tentang orang tua, keluarga, kasih sayang, keluarga bahagia, rumor, bentuk dari mental illness, restoran, pikiran yang 'sakit', dan... obsesi. Sungguh sebuah buku yang (tidak aku sangka) menarik. [NR/18]

100 halaman pertama, ga ada kejadian berarti, ga ada konflik apapun yang muncul. Tapi setelahnya pertanyaan mulai muncul akibat kejanggalan dan kejadian di hidup si tokoh utama ini. Narasinya pakai sudut pandang orang pertama, yang bisa dibilang ... aneh (setelah baca review dari beberapa orang, ternyata si tokoh utama ini punya kelainan/penyakit mental).Selain itu, gue kurang nyaman dengan perpindahan setting waktu di novel ini. Jelas sih perpindahannya, tapi kurang nyaman bagi gue. Selain itu, si tokoh utama ini terlalu banyak mikirin hal-hal yang menurut gue remeh.Misterinya bikin gue pengen terus baca. Ada sesuatu dari narasi cerita yang meskipun ga nyaman, tapi ketika gue taro buku ini untuk istirahat sebentar, ada perasaan penasaran, kenapa dan apa yang akan terjadi selanjutnya? Akan dibawa kemana cerita ini? Apakah pembaca akan langsung dikasih jawaban atau diputer-puter dulu (hampir tiga perempat buku ini memang muter-muter ceritanya).Ketika konfliknya mulai menanjak dan gue udah berpikir macem-macem tentang klimaksnya, ternyata ... ga terlalu mencengangkan. Tapi (lagi-lagi setelah baca penjelasan di review beberapa orang) ternyata di balik tindakan yang dilakukan keluarga ini, ada penyakit mental yang mendasarinya. Jadi kalau dipikir-pikir lagi, cerita ini memang tentang orang-orang 'sakit'.

Yang bikin drop adalah sinopsisnya bagus, bikin penasaran dan berekspektasi lebih ternyata ceritanya jauh dibawah ekspektasi saya. Ditambah lagi endorsenya "Gone Girl versi Eropa", yang bikin naik banget harapan saya.Alur ceritanya maju terus mundur ke masa lalu lagi terus kembali ke masa kini lagi. Kadang penempatannya pas dengan ceritanya, kadang bikin kesel karena saat konfliknya mulai memanas tiba-tiba ada cerita flashback kejadian yang dialami si "aku" ini. Apalagi menjelang ending rasanya menyebalkan harus baca kejadian dahulu yang mungkin penting tapi rasanya jadi nggak penting karena penempatannya nggak sesuai. Kenapa nggak ditaruh di bagian awal sampai ke tengah supaya endingnya bener2 klimaks.Yang dialami si tokoh aku ini juga nggak dieksplor dengan baik. Sejak awal sih emang udah keliatan dia punya "masalah" tapi sampe akhirnya selesai nggak ada penjelasan lebih soal "masalahnya" itu.Dan masalah yang mereka perbincangkan di makan malam itu ternyata nggak sepanas yang di bayangkan. Cuma sekedar numpang lewat dan lalu masuk ke penyelesaian.Tadinya mau memberikan satu bintang saja buat buku ini, cuma saya menyukai endingnya yang cukup "sakit jiwa"...2/5

The Dinner adalah novel yang paling aku ingin baca begitu melihat dari covernya dan dari summary di bagian belakang bukunya. Tapi ketika novel The Dinner ini sudah sampai di tanganku, aku sendiri merasa kesulitan untuk menyukai novel ini. Awalnya aku berpikir kalau novel ini akan banyak menyelidiki tentang kasus pembunuhan atau sebagainya, tapi ternyata yang disuguhkan justru lebih banyak konflik batin dari si tokoh utama. Dan pada akhirnya aku memutuskan untuk berhenti membaca novel ini di 3/4 perjalanan yang sudah aku lalui. Secara pribadi, aku bukannya kecewa dengan cerita yang disuguhkan, aku cukup menikmatinya. Tapi mungkin karena aku tidak mampu menyelaraskan apa yang aku pikirkan dengan alur cerita yang diberikan, dan juga karena ekspektasiku di awal sudah salah masalah kontek novelnya, jadilah aku memberikan 2 bintang saja.

hufff, akhirnya bisa nyelesaiin buku ini. banyak tugas dan kesibukan nyita waktu banget, bisa baca buku ini seminggu sekali aja udah seneng banget rasanya hehe, #curhat.menurutku konfliknya udah kerasa banget di awal-awal, dan emang bikin greget giru sih. gaya bahasa penulis pun mudah dipahami gitu, ga kaya kebanyakan penulis luar lainnya yang bahasanya cenderung susah dimengerti. penulis juga suka menuliskan part alur mundur, dan ceritanya menurutku lebih bagus dan aku lebih interest sama alur mundur ketimbang cerita yang sedang terjadi, bener bener pengen ada the dinner 2. buku herman koch pertama yang aku baca dan aku suka <3, good

3,8 stars. Belum 4 bintang karena di awal sampai tengah cerita terasa membosankan dan membingungkan, tapi plot twist nya lumayan bagus. Lupakan Gone Girl karena ceritanya sangat berbeda. Unlikeable characters? Of course they are exist in this book, otherwise I'd be disappointed. Lohman family is seriously dysfunctional, all of them. Mungkin banyak yang akan ngga suka karena endingnya unsettling dan bukan happy ending, seakan the devil wins, but this book explores how society and family can be so cruel if necessary in this era. Agak2 keinget novel Akiyoshi Rikako yamg Holy Mother, bedanya "kejahatan" di buku ini dilakukan semua anggota keluarga

idenya bagus, penjabaran cerita juga detail, tapi endingnya mengecewakan. sesuka apapun dengan tema kisahnya, saya tetap #timkeadilanharusditegakkan, bukan hanya fokus pada ke-"sakitjiwa"-an para tokoh.

Serge yang sejak awal adalah orang yang diplot sebagai tokoh paling dibenci ternyata jauh lebih baik dari tokoh lain yang penuh kepalsuan.

Memang, awalnya novel ini berjalan cukup membosankan dan lambat. Namun pada akhirnya, The Dinner bisa menghadirkan cerita yang menegangkan ditambah dengan permasalahan politik dan keluarganya. Sayang, aku nggak bisa menyandingkan ini dengan Gone Girl :') (bcs Amy Elliot-Dunne is better than this)
Di bagian awal terlalu basa-basi jadi cukup membosankan. DI pertengahan mulai tahu permasalahannya dan mulai penasaran. Namun, endingnya "trus cuma kayak gitu?".
Plot yg dibangun dari awal sudah bagus tapi twist-nya kurang greget

Malauradament sovint ens arriben noticies de crims comesos per joves adolescents. Aquest llibre, inspirat en el crim del caixer automàtic de Barcelona en que uns joves van cremar una indigent que dormia, parla sobretot de la reacció del pares dels assassins. És tracta però d'una reacció encaminada bàsicament a trobar una solució de caire pragmàtic per els seus fills. Esperava que en algun moment el llibre aprofundís mes en el sentiments d' aquests pares. Què es deu sentir al descobrir que el teu fill ha comès un crim tant terrible? Com t'enfrontes a la realitat? De que parles amb el teu fill i amb la seva mare? Amb un estil molt irònic, sovint humorístic, l' autor juga amb el contrast de personalitats dels protagonistes. Per una banda un pare malalt, insegur, amb gran sentiment de culpa i que és víctima també de la ràbia i l'enveja envers el seu germà -el pare d'un altre dels joves criminals- que és un famós polític amb possibilitats de guanyar les imminents eleccions.

Jeg gik ind til bogen, uden at vide noget. Til at starte med morede jeg mig fint, men langsomt sneg ubehaget og vantroen sig ind på mig, for de to familier der har sat hinanden stævne på en restaurant, viser sig, at være meget anderledes end man lige forventer.
En rigtig god og velkomponeret bog. Bogen er meget anderledes i sin opbygning, er både humoristisk og grusom. Den er virkelig værd at læse.

Immer öfter taste ich mich jetzt in die Welt der Erwachsenen-Literatur vor. Ich finde es jedes Mal wieder erfrischend eine Geschichte nicht durch die Augen eines Teenagers sondern z.B. durch die eines Elternteils zu sehen. Die denken einfach anders, haben andere Probleme und Prioritäten. Im Fall von Angerichtet sind das äußerst brisante Vorfälle: Wie reagiert man, wenn das eigene Kind ein Gewaltverbrechen begeht, einem fremden Menschen etwas zu Leide tut? Ist man schockiert? Kann man das überhaupt richtig akzeptieren? Sucht man die Schuld bei anderen oder ist man gar selbst das lebende Vorbild? Neben dieser sehr persönlichen Thematik werden auch Debatten zu Rassismus und Selbstjustiz aufgeworfen. Wer hat was verdient und wer entscheidet das? Ich liebe es, wenn Autoren sich mit so kontroversen Fragen auseinander setzen und dabei unterschiedlichste Gedankenwelten entblößen.Die Erzählstruktur hat mir ausgezeichnet gemundet. Neben dem kulinarischen Ambiente bekam ich nämlich immer wieder einen überraschenden Happen Information geliefert, den ich im ersten Moment nicht zuordnen konnte. Wenige Minuten später wurde dann aber einen Schritt zurückgegangen, der Kontext erklärt und das Gesamtmenü hat sich erschlossen. Während so Gang für Gang aufgetischt wurde, haben sich schleichend meine Sympathien verschoben. Das Ehepaar, das ich zu Beginn als die netten, liebenden Eltern wahrgenommen hatte, hing plötzlich fragwürdigen Gedanken nach und offenbarte überraschende Taten. Wirklich clever eingefädelt vom Autor. Das Ende ist ziemlich krass und gewagt. Mich hat es nicht direkt befriedigt, aber es lässt viel Raum für Diskussion offen. Ich kann mir den Roman sehr gut als Buchclub-Lektüre vorstellen – am besten über einem 3-Gänge-Menü besprechen.
Mich hat schon lange nichts mehr so gegruselt wie dieses Buch. Die Richtung, in die sich die Charaktere der Familie entwickeln, habe ich so nicht erwartet.

Paul aus dessen Sicht das Drama geschildert wird geht mit seiner Frau und seinem Bruder Serge, sowie dessen Frau Barbara in ein Sternelokal. Das Tischthema ist belanglos, Filme und Urlaub bis immer mehr das eigentliche Thema präsent wird. Die Kinder der Familie, welche befreundet sind und etwas Unglaubliches getan haben. Durch Rückblenden und aktuelle Ereignisse zwischen den Essensgängen wird erst ganz langsam entwirrt was nun eigentlich passiert ist. Das ist so genial mit lästenden und witzigen Anmerkungen zu dem anderen Paar und dem arroganten Personal des Restaurants geschrieben, das man sich an den Nebentisch wünschte. Jeder der dieses spannende Drama liest wird sich am Ende Fragen wie weit dürfen Eltern gehen um ihre zu Tätern gewordenen Kinder zu schützen.Ich fand dieses Buch sehr bewegend und frage mich ernsthaft, ob so manche 'Übereltern' deren Kinder immer alles unglaublich gut können und überhaupt unfehlbar sind wirklich objektiv urteilen können, wenn ihre Kinder Mist bauen?magog89 von MexxBooks

Anfangs musste ich immer wieder "Gott des Gemetzels" denken - zwei Paare treffen sich um über ein Problem ihrer Kinder zu sprechen und lassen ihrer Antipathie einander gegenüber letztendlich freien Lauf -, dann änderte sich jedoch die Dynamik. In den Vordergrund rückten Fragen des moralisch richtigen Verhaltens. (view spoiler)[Ich muss gestehen, mich hat der unzuverlässige Erzähler überrascht, dessen Wahrnehmung ich erst sehr spät kritisch überprüft habe. Da ergaben endlich auch die auffallend häufigen Gewaltfantasien und das paranoid anmutende Geheimhalten gewisser Informationen Sinn. (hide spoiler)] Der Roman war flüssig zu lesen und vermochte mich bis zum letzten Viertel auch zu packen, dann hatte ich jedoch inhaltlich immer mehr meine Mühe, was sich zwar letztendlich erklärte, aber dennoch ein schales Gefühl zurückließ. Vielleicht ist genau dies die Absicht des Autors gewesen? Dennoch führt es dazu, dass ich von 4 (für die Anfang- und Mittelteil) auf knapp 3 Sterne runtergehe (Gesamteindruck). Auf jeden Fall ein Buch, das inhaltlich einiges an Diskussionsstoff bietet.
Sehr gut geschrieben, sprachlich sehr flüssig und exakt. Der Autor verführt den Leser zum Spiel mit dem Bösen. Man muss aufpassen nicht von „Der Dunklen Seite der Macht“ ergriffen zu werden.

Dieses Buch ... war seltsam. Ich habe es zum Geburtstag geschenkt bekommen und habe mich auch sehr darüber gefreut. Es ist zwar eins, nach dem ich niemals selbst im Bücherregal gegriffen hätte, aber gerade das liebe ich auch an geschenkten Büchern. Ich wollte mich jedenfalls drauf einlassen. Schließlich und letzendlich hat mich das 1/3 des Buches aber einfach nur gelangweilt. Es war pures Gejammere, das von Seite zu Seite schlimmer wurde. Das konnte auch der gewitzte Schreibstil nicht kaschieren. Es ist sehr sehr sehr schnell klar geworden, dass die Haupterperson seine Frau liebt, seinen Sohn beschützen möchte und vor allem, dass er seinen Bruder hasst. Er lässt sich in diesem ersten Drittel (und auch darüber hinaus)fast ausschließlich nur über seinen Bruder aus. Was dazu führt, dass weder Bruder noch Hauptperson sonderlich sympathisch macht. Fast hätte ich es weggelegt, wenn es dem Autor nicht gelungen wäre, den unterschwelligen Konflikt nicht auf eine Art und Weise anzudeuten, der einem im zweiten Drittel des Buches einfach denken lässt: jetzt sag es mir doch einfach und gut ist die Sache und im dritten Teil schließlich nur noch: und wie löst ihr es jetzt? Leider sind beide Punkte vom Autor als zu klischeehaft oder gar nicht beantwortet worden. Über stilistische Mittel lässt sich bekanntlich streiten, aber mehrere wichtige Auslöser nur anzudeuten oder mit einem lächerlichen Verweis auszulassen, finde ich indiskutabel. Darüber hinaus ist der Brüderkonflikt, der ja einen Großteil der Geschichte ausmacht, meiner Meinung nach nur ein Symptom des eigentlichen Problems, was der Autor mehr als nur deutlich macht und dennoch bekommen wir vom Symptom mehr mit als vom Problem. Das ist schade. Für die Idee zolle ich dem Autor nämlich durchaus Respekt. Die Art und Weise wie eine Familie (selbst eine verrüttete) mit dem Problem umgegangen wäre, finde ich sehr spannend - leider liefert der Autor hier gar nichts. Mehr noch, die ganze Grundlage seines Buches "Angerichtet" geht meiner Meinung nach Baden, da NIEMAND für ein solch heikles Thema in ein verdammtes Restaurant gehen würde. Mir ist durchaus bewusst, dass das Setting über die Dramatik hinaus vielleicht noch eine andere Bedeutung hatte, aber die hätte ich gerne im Buch erklärt bekommen! Alles in allem glänzt dieser Roman also leider hauptsächlich duch bemüht dramatische Handlung, die eigentlich nur durch Plotlöcher lebt, durchweg unsympathischen Charakteren und ihren unlogischen Handlungen, sowie einer großartigen aber verschenkten Idee. Lediglich der Schreibstil beeindruckt durch viel Witz und erlaubt außerdem ein schnelles Ende :D

Was für ein großartiges Buch! Wenngleich es in Erinnerungen des Ich-Erzählers durchaus verschiedene Schauplätze gibt, ist das Ganze atmosphärisch jedoch so dicht gewebt wie ein Kammerspiel. Diese Geschichte ist spannend und mitreißend, sehr besonders, innovativ und dazu erschreckend und verstörend. Dies umso mehr, insofern ich persönlich mich zu Beginn mehrere Male sehr gut mit dem Protagonisten identifizieren, mich in seinen Darlegungen und Motivationen wiederfinden konnte - eben jener Protagonist, der sich im Laufe der Erzählung doch als jemand ganz Anderes entpuppt, als anfangs gedacht...

Kurzweiliger als "Sommerhaus mit Swimmingpool", das ich vorher gelesen hatte, aber sonst sehr ähnlicher. Unsympathischer misanthroper Hauptdarsteller, der niemanden liebt, außer seiner Familie. Es gab mehr Handlung und Dialoge, daher ließ es sich ganz gut lesen. Ansonsten war es wieder die Familie als Bollwerk gegen den Rest der Welt, die es mit allen Mitteln zu schützen gilt, Gewalt bis hin zum Mord eingeschlossen. Das Thema an sich ist gar nicht schlecht, aber die Figuren einfach alle so total unsympathisch, dass der Lesespaß auf der Strecke bleibt.

Ich LIEBE diesen Autor !! ich hatte zuerst "Sommerhaus mit Swimmingpool", der deutsche Titel dieses Buches leitet "Angerichtet" - ein viel zweideutiger und besserer Titel...Zwei Brüder treffen sich mit ihren Frauen zum Essen, von einem netten Familientreffen ist leider nichts zu spüren, denn sie haben ein Problem mit ihren Söhnen, was zu besprechen ist....Gnadenlos ehrlich lässt der Autor in die Abgründe der elterlichen Seelen schauen...spannend und vor allem nachdenklich stimmend....

Hab ich was verpasst? Ich kann das Lob der Kritiker absolut nicht nachvollziehen, finde die "Geschichte" weder toll erzählt noch moralisch herausfordernd. Der Hauptcharakter und Erzähler ist, sorry, ein Arsch, egal, wie ich es betrachte. Ich würde den nicht kennen wollen, und beim Lesen ist mir mehrfach sehr unwohl geworden.

Nach 20% habe ich das Buch zur Seite gelegt. Dauernd wird vom eigentlichen Handlungsstrang abgezweigt und dadurch verliert sich der Leser Buch.
Es geht ins Restaurant und dann? Ein Kochbuch? keine Rezepte gefunden. Ein Krimi? keine Leiche entdeckt.
Einfach nur seicht wie RTL.

Ein sehr sehr gut geschriebenes Buch! Eine Freude, es zu lesen. Kann ich nur empfehlen auch wenn ich nicht mit seiner Theorie der Gewalt einverstanden bin - zu einfach und platt für die sonstige Qualität des Buches.

Fies und ein wenig verstörend. Von seiner Schreibweise und Lesbarkeit her hätte das Buch definitiv drei Sterne verdient, aber weil bei mir das WAS ja immer mehr zählt als das WIE, bleibt es bei zwei Sternen. Das ist einfach überhaupt nicht mein Thema.
Das Buch lässt mich sehr zwiegespalten zurück. Von 5 bis 1 Stern ist alles drin. Da der negative Beigeschmack bei mit blieb als ich es zuschlug: 3 Sterne
hatte angesichts gelungener Schockmomente und Angedeutetem mehr erwartet
Überraschende Wendungen. Mehr kann man nicht sagen, sonst verrät man zu viel. Sehr guter Schreibstil, spannend.
Genial gelesen. ... die Faszination des Grauens!
Tolle Art, eine beunruhigende Geschichte zu verpacken! Super.
Eine Art "dutch psycho", sehr süffiger Stoff.
Krank trifft es ziemlich gut, genauso wie der Schein trügt.

Õõvastav. Lihtsalt õõvastav. Ma tean, et maailmas ei ole ainult häid inimesi, aga võib-olla oleksin pidanud raamatu lugemata jätma & elama oma mullis edasi.

Kui palju me hoolime teiste eludest? Kes on kaalukausi peal olulisem? Mis piirini peab inimene oma lähedast kaitsma? Ja mis kõige hirmsam - kas me võime 100% kindlalt öelda, et meie oleme paremad inimesed.
Kes on näinud eesti mängufilmi "Õnnelind Flamingo", see on pmst ka raamatut lugenud. Teema on sama, lihtsalt hollandi kastmes. Ebaloogilist on palju, see segab.

Mäletan, kui see raamat paar aastat tagasi ilmus ja nüüd kui see kätte sattus tundus tuttav ja seepärast ette võtsingi. Tuleb tunnistada, et see oli võigas lugemiselamus. Teemaks kuritöö ja karistus, vanemate vastutus laste tegude eest. Ja mitte ainult. Perekonna suhted ja õigluse enda kätte võtmine. Kui algus kippus pisut venima, siis kui umbes 50 lehte möödas oli, siis ei saanud tõesti enam käest ära panna. See kõik oli väga realistlik. Minu jaoks on see raamat sarnane Rowlingu "Ootamatu võimalusega", sest siin polnud samuti ligi 300-l lehel ühtegi positiivset tegelast ega meeldivat momenti. Kuigi see on ilukirjandus tuleb vist ka selliseid raamatuid lugeda, et aru saada, millises maailmas me elame.

see on raamat mis ei ole aja möödumisele hästi vastu pidanud, kohati veidi rassistlik ja ei suhtu kodututesse inimestesse kuigi hästi. kui aga need aspektid kõrvale jätta ja sisule keskenduda hoiab raamat võrdlemisi hästi lubatud pinget üleval, jutustus on sujuv ja seda ei olnud eriti raske jälgida, pidevalt tuleb uusi kannapöördeid, tegelased on üldjuhul reaalsete inimeste moodi, peategelane/jutustaja on samuti üsna mitmetahuline ja ma arvan et tema vaatepunkt annabki raamatule just sellise natuke ebameeldiva õhustiku mis mulle isiklikult isegi vahelduseks meeldis.raamatu keskel oli kirjastiilis ja jutustuses madalhetki, kus ma hakkasin kahtlema kui hea see raamat ikka tegelikult on, aga kuna lõpuks said kõik otsad kinni seotud jäin ma sellega ikkagi rahule. tegelik hinnang oleks kõike arvesse võttes pigem 3.7

Suurem osa raamatust meenutas mingil veidral moel I.Welshi teoseid, ehk oli midagi tema tegelastest "Õhtusöögi" peategelases (nt "Kõntsa" Robertsoni?) aga lõpp läks kahjuks vabalangusesse. Õhtusöök muutus umbes poolest pearoast aina magedamaks, kuni lõppes täiesti seedimatu digestiiviga, jootrahast siis rääkimata.

Ei. Ei. Ei. Ma ei soovitaks seda raamatut mitte kellelegi. See oli tõeliselt halb kirjatükk. (Või peaks ütlema: toode?)Lugedes kavatsesin anda hindeks 1, siis otsustasin, et see võimalus tuleks hoida siiski millegi veel halvema jaoks.Tegevustik oli täiesti ebareaalne ja tegelased ebameeldivad. Või pigem - nendega oli võimatu suhestuda, sest tegelased ei peagi tingimata meeldima, aga mingil moel peab lugejal siiski olema võimalik nendega suhestuda, paremal juhul samastuda. Aga need inimesed olid napakad, naeruväärsed ja ebahuvitavad samal ajal. Raamat tundus olevat konstrueeritud panema lugejaid mõtlema, et tegevuse taustaks on mingi salapärased, sügavad ja tumedad allhoovused, aga kukkus selles osas täielikult läbi, olles üheplaaniline ja tüütu. Süžee areng (oli siin üldse mingi süžee?) oli kohutavalt aeglane, raamatu esimeses pooles ei toimunud üldse midagi ja teine pool oli lihtsalt naeruväärne. Kui ma lugemise lõpetasin, leidsin siiski, et 1 on vääriline hinnang, kuna ma võtan kehvi raamatuid alati isikliku solvanguna ja see raamat kindla peale solvas mind.
Pinge küll keris terve raamatu vältel, kuid siiski ei jõudnud sisu ja mõte kuidagi päris minuni.

Hated this book! It felt contrived and stilted. I didn't like any of the characters. I couldn't identify with any of them. None of the dialogue was believable. The situation was farcical (why would you go to a super-expensive, elite restaurant to talk about such a private matter?). The whole book was about protecting the kids from their own actions - their was no sense of personal responsibility, no remorse, no soul searching. The narrator was a violent thug who just whined incessantly the whole way through the book. He was as big a bore as his brother.I can't begin to describe how irritated and ripped off I felt by this book.To compare it to The Slap (by Australian author Christos Tsiolkas) is such a joke. The characters in that book were so well written and, while not always likeable (in fact some were really icky), they were believable. And it explored the underlying issues and fallout from the "event" that the book gets its name from.I felt like the The Dinner was a cheap stunt designed to make the reader feel like they had explored something deep, dark and dangerous. It is white-bread, middle class, lite-lit of the worst kind.

I really detested every character in this book (with the exception of Serge, him I just disliked). I hated the ending with every fiber of my being. I found myself wanting to put it down numerous times, and I felt physically ill when I realized where the ending was going....and yet I didn't hate the book itself. I actually went back and forth about whether to give it three stars or four stars for quite awhile. If it was possible I would give it 3 1/2 stars, so lets just say I did. I am going to leave my review simple for many reasons- 1) You don't need me to tell you what this book is about because there are lots of other people explaining the plot on Goodreads, and they will do it much better than me (writing down my thoughts has never been my forte)... 2) I have just started to voice my opinions on here, and my thoughts on this book would make me sound like a " raving, people hating, I weep for the future" kind of gal...and finally 3) If I get into my feelings of THE DINNER I will probably give something away (since I don't know how to use the spoiler warning yet). I feel to get the most enjoyment out of reading it, you really should go in blind.

so this is probably a safe bet for people who liked Gone Girl. in other words, not you, richard. but it is not nearly as twisty and satisfying as g.g., methinks. it has the moral bankruptcy of Gone Girl, the shallow people, banal small talk and heavily-done descriptive elements of American Psycho, and the "we are here to talk about our delinquent kids but it isn't going to go well" scenario of The God of Carnage. and why yes, i have only seen the film adaptation, thank you for asking.the whole thing takes place over a single dinner, with each section of the book corresponding to a course in the meal. the participants are two couples; a pair of resentful brothers and their wives, and the occasion is not a festive one, but a sit-down to discuss the horrific crime their sons have committed together, whether to tell the authorities, and how this will impact the one's plans in his campaign for prime minister of the netherlands.the restaurant itself is a nightmare - the kind of place you have to wait three months for a table (unless you are serge lohman, beloved prime minister-to-be), and they serve you mostly plate and insist on telling you all about the ingredients and from whence they came, and how the little baby calves were petted and loved until they were turned into sweetbreads. so the story becomes this juxtaposition of the violence of their children against the trappings of the entitled bourgeoisie.(oh, greg is going to be so proud of me)but it's an odd little book. maybe it is the translation, but it is very stilted, whose characters seem like when aliens wear human faces, and not just because of how reprehensible some of them are in their little moral cesspool. the storytelling itself is very skewed - there are amazingly minute details about the food and its cost, but it gleefully glosses over the important stuff. which is coy and intentional, but frustrating for the reader, who really wants to know what psychological disorder our increasingly unreliable narrator suffers from. as the story goes on, the tension escalates, and with every course, as the waiter's finger comes closer and closer to the food as he relentlessly describes every element on the plate, you can feel the simmer of the unspoken building to a boil.there is a lot of violence in this book. there is the crime itself, but there are also numerous flashback stories and memory sequences, where violence is alluded to and then celebrated in ever-increasing swathes of confession. while still doing the coy thing, the discreet turn away from the camera when it comes time to make with some of the details.ultimately, the book is about protecting family vs doing what is right, but "right" in this case is subjective, and two of our subjects just don't have the same compass as us; they have a nick-and-amy compass. so things are going to get rough.it's perfectly good, it just didn't make me see stars.bon appetit!!come to my blog!

“That’s the oppressive thing about happiness, the way everything is out on the table like an open book.”
 When you look at the "rating details" for every widely-read book on Goodreads, you will almost always see most ratings being 5 or 4 stars. Even when it comes to divisive books like Fifty Shades of Grey, 60% of the ratings are for 4 or 5 stars. Now look at the ratings for The Dinner. There are an overwhelming number of 3 star ratings (more than any other). And I get why. This is the kind of book that you remember as being "clever" and "twisted" but never rush out to recommend. It's a book you find it hard to say isn't "good", but at the same time you weren't blown away. And, though it may be about a dinner, it just isn't that delicious.The whole story consists of one dinner at one of those overpriced restaurants where you get a tiny morsel of food in the centre of your plate. Two couples are at this meal - the narrator (Paul), his politician brother (Serge Lohman), and their wives (Claire and Babette). Through little flashbacks and side stories, details and vagueness, it becomes clear that there's a dark side to this get together and our narrator might not be so reliable.It's a book about many things: mental illness, dehumanization, middle class people and the coveted notion of a "happy family". I particularly liked how Koch explored the ways in which subtle language changes can be used to dehumanize someone. Like calling a drunk person an "alcoholic" so that's what they become - defined by their drunken state, no longer human, deserving of everything they get.It's a book that gets darker and darker. And, despite the scope of the novel being relatively small, it remains compelling. The narrator's disdain for his pretentious brother and the general faff of "posh" restaurants is amusing.Though I think, most of all, this novel has a severe lack of believability and I found it hard to take seriously. Not because I don't believe people are this morally bankrupt - not that at all - but there's a certain farcical nature to the characters' actions. Would they really go out to eat at a restaurant when having a discussion like this? Would Claire really react the way she did at the end (before leaving the restaurant)?The Dinner is thought-provoking. It's twisted. It's good. But there are just enough problems with it that I can't rate higher than 3 stars.

Say you have a terrorist in the family. You see it on the news and then find irrefutable evidence in your own home. Would you protect the person from the police? Would you get together with your family to discuss the situation and all of you agree that further crimes will need to be committed by the family in order to protect their loved one? Would you encourage these crimes and even commit them yourself? Would you do all this in the certain knowledge that the person will do it again and again and again if you protect them? Shock, horror, right? But we see it must be happening.What about if it was your son and he was a killer? We all know this happens in gangs too. We all wonder if it is what happens in the families of serial killers.This is a hypothetical book, one of conjectures. It leads you slowly through the action, at each stage asking you to question yourself, do you find this acceptable, would you do this yourself, what kind of moral action do you expect (or not) from private and public citizens? It asks where responsibility lies and how much nurture v nature is responsible for our ethical conduct. It is an onion book, slowly slowly peeling the skin and the layers until you get to, through tears, the seed, the seed which could grow and form a new generation. A book of horrors. It's a what-if book and one very apposite for the times.I started to read the book in print but it was very slow indeed. Later I understood why there was such a need for a big build-up but it was hard going and I gave it up for the audio book which had a wonderful narrator that brought the character of Paul, the raconteur and only voice of the story to life. At first I thought the ending, a psychological excuse was a cop-out but then without it the book would have not involved the narrator (and his wife) quite so intimately.People have said that the characters were not likeable, true. Well generally that does make it hard to enjoy a book, but not this one. If the characters had been likeable it wouldn't have been a 5-star read because then they would have been like us and this is never going to happen in our lives. I hope._______________If you've read the book and thought nothing like that could ever really happen, read the news. It chilled me to the bone. If you haven't read it, it's not so much a spoiler because the book is different. Kind of.Rewritten 23rd Nov 2019

It occurred to me by the end that this is a fascist novel. Not in the sense that the author is fascist or anything of the sort, but rather like pointing to a certain book and recognizing that it's a feminist novel, or a queer novel, or a Southern novel, or what have you. In 'The Dinner' we have a situation in which the narrator, through a long illuminating story, reveals to the reader the picture of what a secret contempt of all things “weak” or “inferior”—formulated into an ideology and informing violent reactions—is basically, for all intents and purposes, fascist. The narrator Paul Lohman, and his wife Claire, unlikeable and repulsive that they end up being in the novel, make decisions that at first might seem unbelievable, until their history is further revealed. The fascist beliefs only become clear towards the end of the book. Interestingly, the concept of "happiness" is a running theme throughout the book. In the beginning, the narrator Paul quotes 'Anna Karenina' when he says that, "Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." As Paul rails against elite society and the idea of "keeping up appearances," he and his family do just that: they believe in fictions that will keep them, on the surface, "happy." Yet, as "unhappy" and chilling realities unfold, page by page he constantly evokes how happy they are, even as the actions prove Tolstoy's claim. And, like Tolstoy warns, they are "unhappy" in a very unique way.Though, the book leaves you with an icky feeling, it is somehow very enjoyable. It might have something to do with the impulse to view the world through the eyes of someone we would never want to be. It's voyeuristic, but you can't look away. In the end, we might say to ourself, "At least I'm not THAT screwed up."

The Wall Street Journal has tagged The Dinner as ‘the European Gone Girl’. I beg to differ and I think that this book should more appropriately be tagged ‘the European Defending Jacob'...but hey who am I to question The Wall Street Journal! The Dinner tells the story of two families, the parents of which meet each other over dinner one evening in an exclusive restaurant in Amsterdam. At the heart of the story is a horrific crime which both sons within each family hold equal responsibility.Koch has managed to achieve an attention-grabbing, gripping and intriguing read in this book. It is very well written and translated. I was truly hooked from page one right up until the end. The setting, i.e. the restaurant, works exceptionally well...a setting which we think and imagine will provide intimacy and an appropriate platform for discussion. The setting is an extremely important aspect in this book, because as each course arrives for our diners, our own appetite, hunger and curiosity increase for the unfolding story. Consequently, as each course is served, we are faced with the interruption of the waiter on numerous occasions, explaining the dishes of choice to our four diners. Paul, the narrator of the story becomes increasingly impatient with these interruptions and we the reader do too, not because they are not highly complimentary and a necessary side dish to the story, they are, but they serve to prolong our suspense and anticipation and allow an extremely subtle tension to build . As a result, rather than receive the story in one great dish, we are served it in nibbles and sips, finger-food as such. For me, this was one of the best aspects of the book. This structure really worked superbly. There are no likeable characters in the book and our narrator is totally unreliable, two of my favourite features of a good read. The discussions at the dinner table incorporate a number of themes for debate both for our diners and for us, the reader, and are not only limited to the central crime. The plot in the story really brings to mind certain questions for the reader, how far would we go to protect our children, what actions and decisions would we take or what actions and decisions would we not take, in essence, how far would we go, as parents, to protect the ones we love and cherish? This is indeed dark and gritty but a wonderful and highly entertaining read.Highly recommended if you like contemporary fiction, most especially books with unreliable narrators. This book is also an ideal choice for Book Clubs, providing most entertaining and interesting discussion and opinion topics. One of my favourite reads of 2013 so far!

This may have been one of the worst books I have ever read. I will confess that generally I want to have at least one character that I like. But it's not always necessary. If the plot or situation enthralls me in such a way that I am compelled to keep reading, then I'm happy to. This book however, I kept reading because every review that I read and every recommendation I got from friends said how fabulous this book was. I read to the end hoping it would get better. I hated it. I hated the fact that these entitled kids hurt multiple people because they thought it was fun. I hated that the parents were willing to cover it up, even when they discovered it was a pattern. I hated that the father knew he had a mental illness, that had probably been passed on to his son, but he just found it funny. I hated that the one person who wanted to come clean and do the right thing was presented as an egocentric buffoon. Maybe it isn't that I need characters that I like. Maybe it's that I want to know that there is a moral compass out there. This book was filled with psychopaths with no redeeming qualities. I absolutely cannot recommend it.

This is a gourmet treat, with a bite. I have to confess, I don't have a lot of patience with those who dismiss this book simply because of the unlikeable characters. Of course, it goes without saying that anyone's reason for not liking a book is valid. You're allowed to not like the book for this or any other reason. But if you need likeable characters, and a comeuppance for all bad characters, well, frankly, you are in the WRONG SECTION OF THE LIBRARY.Ahem. Now that I got that out of the way...The book is clever, created in the framework of a dinner at a fine dining restaurant. The sections of the book follow the courses, from Aperitif all the way to Digestif. It takes place in Amsterdam, in an overpriced, hoity-toity restaurant, with two couples who are there to discuss their misbehaving sons.The narrator is funny, snarky, and is our tour guide through the evening. Koch uses delightful sleight of hand throughout the book until the final reveal of what's what, and who's who. He turns the reader into a voyeuristic snoop - I mean, don't we all thrill a little when watching a nasty scene erupt at someone else's table? No? Just me?There are a few weaknesses here, worth mentioning. I found it a little hard to believe that the couples would decide to discuss their sons in a public place, given the 'delicate' subject matter. Also, there are biological explanations given for bad behaviour that I didn't 100% buy. (Later, I came to realise that the "syndrome" described in the book is a metaphor for pathological entitlement which gets passed down from parent to child by a lifetime of examples.) But Koch's writing was strong enough to make me take a morsel, and then another, and before I knew it, I'd finished all courses a pretty happy customer.Many compare this to Gone Girl. From where I sit, this book borrows more from Crime and Punishment - shining a light on the moral elitism of those who believe they can decide that some lives are worth more than others. The entitlement of some people to do as they please, regardless of the consequences. Those who respond with a frightening smile or laugh in the face of a ghastly deed done to someone who "deserved it". And, even more chilling, enabling the next generation to be this way.It's dark and it's awful, but it didn't take my appetite away... I'm sure to read more by Herman Koch.

I thought about one of my favorite scenes from STRAW DOGS. What would this artificial voice sound like if its owner were to be dragged into a barn by a pair of French bricklayers? So drunk they could no longer tell the difference between a woman and the ruins of a cottage with only the walls still standing? Would she still be shooting off her mouth...The sequel to GONE GIRL. Two white, rich, soulless, violent sociopaths have a child and that child is growing up to become a soulless, violent sociopath as well.You get the idea that something is wrong with our narrator, Paul, early on. He loves the movies DELIVERANCE and STRAW DOGS and he often fantasizes about punching people and killing them.It's only later that you realize that he has put multiple people in the hospital.And it's not until very close to the end of the novel that you realize his wife is just as bad as he is. Until then you have a hope or a sympathy that perhaps she is a good person.The son they create is exactly the kind of son you'd think would be created by the union of and then raising by two monsters. The kind of rich kid who sets a homeless woman on fire and thinks it's funny and is actually a favor to society.I can't say this book is very fun to read."Mr. Lohman," he said. Then I punched him squarely in the nose. Right away there was blood, lots of blood: it sprayed from his nostrils and splattered across his shirt and the desktop, and then on the fingers with which he pawed at his nose.By that time I had come around the desk and hit him in the face again, lower down this time. His teeth hurt my knuckles as they broke off. He screamed.I know GONE GIRL shocked and titillated the world by putting two horrible protagonists in the book, and that was fine. But now I feel like this is not only old hat, but rather painful to read. There's no resolution. No one gets their comeuppance or punishment. Good people are murdered and maimed and the soulless go on with their existence, happy and rich and complete. THE END. Does this satisfy anyone? It might be fun in a shocking way if it's the first book of this kind you've ever read, but if you've read GONE GIRL then this is going to be more of the same for you.It's realistic.I'm laughing at how many people defend this kind of novel by saying, "Well, it's realistic." or "That's just how life is." Evil people do evil things and get away with them, feel no remorse and are never caught or punished. Great, fine. It's realistic. That's not why I read fiction, emphasis on 'fiction.' I certainly don't need everything neat and tidy, but if you expect me to be happy with this kind of novel, you are wrong.What I feel when I shut this book is despair, disappointment, and apathy. That's NOT the way I want a book to make me feel. I am very disinterested in this burgeoning subgenre called "sick fucks kill and hurt people, then live happy and long lives being sick fucks and raising other sick fucks." That's not appealing to me on any level.Tl;dr - Did you love GG and hope another book would be JUST LIKE THIS?!!?! Here's your fix. However, if you are tired and annoyed of MCs with no shred of humanity, not even the tiniest shred - stay far away from this, which seems like a tired re-hash of ideas already hashed.P.S. Also, this book purports that being a soulless sick fuck is an inherited genetic trait. And that you can sense this disease - be tested for it when you are in utero, amniotic fluid test - and if your fetus has this disease you should abort it. It's strongly hinted in the book that Koch's talking about Asperger's. What a bunch of shit. All of this is shit. What is this, The Bad Seed, where some people are born soulless, and just "Oh, well." Nurture has nothing to do with it, I mean, you're either born a sick fuck or someone with normal feelings. AND ANOTHER THING. People with Asperger's are fine. What is this author implying? If you are on the autism spectrum or not neurotypical that you are a murdering asshole who maims and kills people when things don't go your way?I wish this whole "I have a disorder, we should have aborted my now-15-year-old-son in the womb because people with this neurological disorder are soulless and will probably become serial killers" was left out. I mean, what the fuck, dude? If you just realized the dad (the main character) was fucked up, and then got to toy around with the idea in your mind like, "Nature or nurture? Is his son soulless because he inherited his dad's no-soul gene, or did growing up with a dad who literally bashed people's faces into a bloody pulp when they got in his way make his child think such behavior was acceptable?" this would be more palatable to me. But no, Koch has to make Paul (the MC dad) go to a psychologist who informs him that if they had had in-utero testing 30 or 40 years ago, Paul himself would've been aborted. Because being a soulless killer is an "illness" that can be detected in the womb and preemptively stopped.Fuck this shit. Koch comes off as an ableist jerk here, demonizing autism and Asperger's and thinking he can get away with it because he doesn't say "the A-word," as my friend calls it.This book is really angering me on many levels. Isn't it difficult enough to navigate a neurotypical world without having people write books about autistic killers who go around murdering people? I'm very angry.P.P.S. People keep saying "This book is about the lengths you'll go to protect your family" and to me that is not what this book was about, AT ALL. I guess every reader does read a different book.RELATED BOOKS:Gone GirlA Bum Deal: An Unlikely Journey from Hopeless to Humanitarian

This is a book that polarises opinion. In some respects it could be viewed as being provocative, voyeuristic and dark; in other ways it could be seen as being unpleasant and incredibly dull.I, for instance, love the movie Lost in Translation and consider it to be a masterpiece. My wife, on the other hand, finds it ponderous and aimless. As an inveterate people watcher, I love witnessing families having bust-ups in restaurants and other public places, as long as I'm not anywhere near them. I also watch cringeworthy social gaffes on TV through my fingers, all the while groaning with embarrassment, yet continuing to gawp.So, if (like me) you love to eavesdrop while fragile relationships unravel in restaurants, then this might be your thing. If you prefer your main characters to all be agreeable and charming, then this definitely won't suit!

Wow! What a fun dinner experience that was!Everything was going so well during drinks and appetizers. Just a nice meal in a super fancy restaurant. Luckily, Serge knew people since he was a politician and all, maybe even the next prime minister! The first third of the book was just that... appetizers, whetting my appetite for the delicious main course. Pages and pages of beautiful descriptions, subtle humor, not so subtle humor, and casual conversation. The whole book could have stayed right there and I wouldn't have minded at all. But, ohhh what happened.... We gotta talk about the children. And that's when the main course got really, really dark and you got to know everyone a little too well, more details than you ever wanted to know, stories of the past that shouldn't really be unearthed. Not here, not at dinner. People will say, "Ugh, I didn't like any of the characters. They were all so awful. Boo hoo hoo." I didn't like any of these people either. I was never rooting for anyone. I don't think that's the point of the book. Yeah, it seems absurd that these parents had to make what we may see as easy decisions, right? But, man, we're not running for prime minister, and aren't we all selfish at our core anyway? Doesn't this maybe point out that we're probably always going to look out for ourselves, and isn't that worse? How different am I from these people? Ahhhh!!I loved the twists and turns of the novel, diving into Paul's past and his relationship with his brother. It didn't turn these people into anti-heroes or make me feel for them, but it made them three dimensional even if they were still pretty awful. The way this book took a sharp turn and didn't lay off the brakes from there was fantastic. I didn't think there was a moment wasted, and I loved each section of the meal. I would even argue that it ended a little too abruptly after the slow climb to get there. I would have liked a few more pages, maybe an epilogue or something. I don't know. I was pleasantly surprised by this book. I knocked out most of it in a day. I would definitely recommend it for something a little darker, but please, for the love of God...Don't compare this to Gone Girl.

I'm a huge fan of books that explore how far we'll go for those we love, particularly our children. When Hogarth Publishers agreed to send me the e-galley of The Dinner I was ecstatic. It's due to be published in the states in February 2013. This is a book that begs eating metaphors so I'll try to spare you but it won't be easy. The Dinner is laid out in courses, from aperitif to digestif and is excellently plotted. You learn early on that this dinner is not the typical happy family outing. Brothers Serge and Paul and their wives have met to discuss their children and some trouble the boys, cousins Rick and Michel have gotten themselves into. It's not immediately apparent whether this trouble is the usual stuff the poor judgment of teens produces or if it's something more serious. The tension at the table is evident from the get-go. The rivalry between Paul and Serge is palatable. Serge picked the restaurant, over priced and showy where only someone with his celebrity status could hope to get a table. He's running for and likely to become the next Prime Minister. In contrast, Paul is an out of work former teacher carrying lots of baggage. Between apertif and dessert, with the in-between courses going from civilized to acrid hostility, the no good deed is revealed. What lengths will these parents go to in order to save their child?When I last picked up my napkin, dabbed my lips and placed it on the table, I wish there were a character I liked. None were appetizing and I was left feeling a bit nauseous. Not quite content and yet, wanting no more, even though some morsel was missing. Call for the check and let me out of here.Given time to digest, I relished in the deliciousness of the plot and this serving of evil. There's enough to chew on here for a good book discussion.3.5 stars with a look for more from this author.

Update :I got the dvd of the movie of this book, and just as I was about to play it I said to myself hold on, I already watched this movie; and then I wasn't sure - had I already seen it or not? What a puzzle! but then myself answered back and said that the only way to find out was to watch it, so I did and I hadn't seen the movie at all.But the book had instilled such strong scenes and dialogues within the portals of my brain that I thought I had. I think that deserves another half star. And I do recommend the dvd, a very bitter affair, less hideously funny than the book, and arguably better. Except for Steve Cogan pretending to be an American - I don't know why they do that. It's like Dr Johnson's dog walking on two legs.*******Original review :They say, do they not, that The Dinner is the European Gone Girl. Mais non! I say. I threw GG at the wall after around page 100 with some force, but I finished The Dinner with a distinct smacking of the chops and dabbing of the napkin, so that’s a big difference. Both books are about extremely irritating people, it must be admitted. But the plot swerves in GG are more than a little ridiculous and there for the standard lo-cal thriller effect, whereas I thought the disturbed and frankly nasty personalities on display here were just this side of plausible and therefore gave me a frisson, which sounds like something you could eat but isn’t.It’s hard to discuss the plot. You know it’s all about one single dinner in a very posh restaurant so the whole book is one evening from around 8 to around 1 am but with copious flashbacks. The ultra-sophistication of the restaurant brought me out in a cold sweat all by itself, with the maître d’ hovering by each dish and explaining what is on the plate – “The goat’s cheese comes from the Rarata-Monteoru region of Romania. It is an organic farm established by monks in 1459. Each goat has a nominated chef to attend its dietary needs etc etc”. So all that is quite amusing. It is two brothers and their wives who are eating this dinner. Or actually pecking at it then jumping up and rushing outside to make a mysterious phone call. Gradually the ghastly family secrets are unveiled. Each brother has a 15 year old son and the two of them have been spoiler-oiler which is enough to put a person off his escargots. It turns out that the brother who is narrating is spoiler-spoil so you just don’t know what a guy like that will do. So very spoilerish things have happened and indeed will happen. And I cannot say any more than that. I rattled through this and as I did the movie was already forming in my brain. I see fluid camerawork swirling round and round the table and many revolting close-ups of the fancy grub. IMDB says it will be out next year starring Richard Gere, Laura Linney and Steve Coogan. What? Steve Coogan? Is there time to change that? Three stars. Kind of sort of slightly recommended. Haute cuisine is what they eat in this novel but The Dinner is strictly burger and fries.

If Alfred Hitchcock and Vladmimir Nabokov collaborated on a novel, this book could be the result.I love it. It's an ambitious and awesome blend of suspense, social commentary and satire.Koch is a terrific writer. While he doesn't write with the briliant wordplay of Nabokov (that's not Koch's style) there's a tone and a way with the material that reminds me of Nabokov. And he creates suspense with the skill of Hitchcock, who also had that wink-wink thing going while he was terrifying the audience. They also both excelled at the unreliable narrator, as does Koch with his unforgettable Paul.And it's relevant. Even more relevant today than when it was originally published in 2009. And it's probably going to take on greater relevance with time, like "A Clockwork Orange" or "Lord of the Flies."It's a page-turner that lives up to its promise as well as its publicity -- a surprising and thought-provoking, totally unique read. I can't stop thinking about it.
what a vile little book.

I can consider this one of the few messed up novels that amazed me by its darkness. Some of the other ones were Gone Girl and Dark Places, so I guess I do have to agree with the blurb from Wall street journal stating that this is a European Gone Girl. This is one of those circumstances wherein I'm glad I didn't listen to the bad reviews, and the low overall rating of the novel. Opinions vary, so stick with your gut. If the novel seems like something you'd enjoy, then don't hesitate to give it a read.Halfway through the novel I decided to consider this as the epitome of contemporary fiction, among all the novels that I've read so far. It's weird how endless ramblings regarding random things in life kept my attention for more than 100+ pages. Palahniuk tried that style with me, but failed miserably. Koch on the other hand managed to make me like the novel even more because of the rambling. I cared about what he was trying to point out, and everything the main character said only made me like him better.This novel, like I said, was messed up. If you're not a fan of dark fiction, then I'd suggest you avoid this. It's not gut-wrenching in the same way as some gore-y horror movies, but the outcome would make you question the sanity of the characters, or even the author himself. I'm a fan of out of norm fiction, so that means I don't mind if the author tackles on topics that are profane and socially unacceptable. I'm not one to promote such activities, of course, because I'm against them, but writing about those doesn't mean that the author automatically thinks that it's supposed to be right. The plot took a while for it to develop. Halfway through I honestly still didn't know what was the main focus of the novel. The secret wasn't revealed then and I was impatiently waiting for it to be discussed further. At first I thought that the novel was going to have a terrible plot because of its seemingly nonexistent development, but thankfully I was proven wrong.The characters were the main reason why this novel was messed up. Let me add in the fact though that messed up doesn't mean it was bad. I mean messed up in a positive way. Psychologically challenged characters are the best to read about, at least for me. Paul, Claire, Serge, and Babette were all amazing, and fully developed in the end. One or two of the four truly shocked me in the end of the novel. I didn't expect them to develop the way they did but the author knew what he was doing.In the end one may ask, "What was this truly about?". In my opinion, it was about how one would do anything to keep their family safe, no matter what the consequences may be. The love of a couple for their child, and how nothing can stand against that.4.5/5 stars. Why round it down? It's because I needed more. The novel felt like it was cut short too early. The ending was not ambiguous, and I liked what happened in the end. It does feel like a European Gone Girl, so get ready for messed up to the tenth power. Highly recommended for psychological thriller fans, because this felt like a mixture of contemporary and psycho-thriller.

column5: j e w e l s
column7: A delicious, twistalicious book you will want to devour. A definite worthy contender for my TWISTER HALL OF FAME at www.booksbejeweled.com"Sometimes things come out of your mouth that you regret later on. Or no, not regret. You say something so razor-sharp that the person you say it to carries it around with them for the rest of their life."— Herman Koch (The Dinner)  This is one of my favorite books in the domestic noir genre. It is not a book for everyone. It is biting, raw and the darkest humor you can imagine. Almost the entire story is set at a restaurant table.There are two unhappy couples having dinner together and acting as if everything is fine. As we go from appetizers to dessert, the reader gets a sense that something is very wrong here. A simmering beneath the surface kind of tension. It continues to build until all the secrets are exposed. I could not put this book down except for minutes at a time and then I was constantly wondering "what in the world is going on here?"Each couple has a son. These sons are cousins to each other, because their dads are brothers.  The sons have done something horrible. Really bad. And the parents are here not just to eat dinner at a fancy restaurant, but to work out how this situation their sons are in should be handled. All four members at the table have a different agenda, a different perspective, a different personality flaw.The narrator, Paul, is sarcastic and funny and relatable. He could be someone you know. But when you find out the true Paul, who he is when no one is watching, you realize you probably don't know anyone like him and you certainly don't want to.To me, this book is a rare find. It is very well written, even though it is translated from Dutch to English. Amazing, the English major in me rejoices! A brilliant and literary, domestic suspense story.

I understand comparing a book to Gone Girl will push sales, so yay for that comparison plastered on every The Dinner reference. But seriously, motherfuckers, this novel is more like Flynn's Sharp Objects and, in my eyes, better than Gone Girl. So let's stop talking about Gone Girl, even though I liked that book, because, you know, there are other books in the goddamn universe and I'm trying to review one as we speak.The Dinner's main character is an angry, reflective guy out at a restaurant with his wife, brother, and sister-in-law. The action unfolds over the evening and through flashbacks. I suppose one of comparisons between The Dinner and the Gillian Flynn-novel-that-will-not-be-named emerges from the fact I couldn't write a review of either without fearing revealing spoilers. Koch's novel is tighter, however, in its focus on familiar relationships, whether they be father/son, mother/son, father/mother, or brother/brother. The narrators gets to articulate the terrific hatred and frustration inherent in minor interactions and (perhaps) over-sensitivity to slights and manipulation when one's mind isn't quite in the right place. And the deep darkness connects to the question of whether or not families can retain a semblance of normalcy or even grow closer when the stakeholders lie, scheme, and withhold, sometimes to each other, sometimes for each other.I very much enjoyed The Dinner. I don't re-read much but I could see myself re-reading the novel in a month or two because the elegant structure deserves a second look. This book is better than its the "European Gone Girl or "topic of countless dinner party debates" horseshit tag lines. Read The Dinner on its own terms.
