It's not a good story nor is it one that makes you think unless inspiring thoughts such as "dear God these people are horrible" counts as making you think.

Already in October I thought I already figured out the worst book I've read this year (Sulphuric Acid). On the 20th of November I had to change my mind again. This is the worst book I've read this year. Picture Gone Girl, We Need to Talk About Kevin and American Psycho - this would be the miscarriage of that love triangle. I strongly believe in the reader's right to abandon an unpleasant read, and believe me, I was extremely temped to abandon it, but the shortness of the novel made me persist and be done with it. The plot idea is quite interesting, even though not really original: two married couples have to meet up at dinner in a fancy restaurant to talk about something dramatic that has to do with their children. Over the main courses, brought to the table and described by the maitre, the narration proceeds slowly, and by page 50 the original interesting idea turns into a banal, obvious ending. Believe me, by page 50 you already get the idea where this is going to. And it's bad. I don't think the issue is the "credibility of the events": we hear the news, we are familiar with current events, these episodes are not too far from the truth. It's the way in which they're told that represents a problem. Not only the language is vile, is unrealistic, it makes you hate each and every character, but it also shows the author's complete lack of understanding of mental health issues. The way in which he portrayes mental health and its degeneration in this novel is awful. It's the depiction a child would made. It looks like a joke, a parody, but it's not the author's intent. It's cringey, it's unrealistic, it's completely detached from the reality of these events and situations. I hated this novel. I hated this with every fiber of my being.

It takes a special kind of masochist to enjoy reading this rotten trash. It's a story that starts off full of mystery and depth but slowly condenses into a cumbersome pile of garbage. The narrator is an insufferable twat devoid of human compassion and because this book is in first-person, anyone hoping to slog through all 318 pages of his contemptuous, pain-inducing narration needs hold their nose and grit their teeth. Truly, the narrator deserves a place among the ranks of the most revolting main characters in all of fiction and having to gleam the story from his perspective is simply agonizing. Abandon hope all ye who enter here, there is no profound insight or exciting drama to be found. There are no heroes, no redemption, just disgusting people having dinner.But speaking seriously, if you wanted to write an edgy, depraved, transgressive novel, you'd need to have a balance between morality and immorality. Any depraved main characters would need to have some redeeming quality to make the readers care about them. There'd need to be a humane element for the readers to hold onto. A Virgil to accompany us through the circles of hell. This book sadly doesn't have that. What a disappointment.

I was hopeful, going into reading this, that I would enjoy it. Unfortunately, that was not the case. First of all, structurally it's a difficult read. I honestly wanted to put it down many times and actually skipped entire paragraphs that were obviously reiterating previous content (there is a lot of that). Secondly, the characters are not relatable by any stretch of the imagination. The author delves into Paul's background but because we are in Paul's head, the character himself omits a lot of information that would make the reader sympathetic to him. We have a vague notion that he has some kind of "illness" which requires medication, that he fails to take. It's hard to find sympathy when the character is controlling the narrative. What you're left with is a bunch of characters you feel nothing about. The only relatable thing in this book is a parent's desire to do anything to protect their children. You know where the story is heading as well as a guess as to how it ends about one third of the way through the book. The most horrifying thing about the storyline is the way a murder of a homeless person is dealt with. None of the characters have any real regard for that person and feel no need to punish their children over it. If the intent was to make me feel absolutely repulsed by most of the characters, then job well done. Absolutely a disappointing read.

I did indeed judge the book by the cover when I picked this book up, by the cover I expected to feel excited and mortified by what was to happen in the book. Well I was indeed mortified. Let me just start from the beginning because the title says it all, they are having a nice civil dinner. Literally nothing interesting for the next 120 pages, I was ready to put the book down, but honestly I despise how a person can say they didn't like a particular book without reading the whole thing so I trudged through it. Next we find out the son killed a homeless person and beats homeless people up for fun. Then as the book progresses we see it switch from a dinner setting and now he's a teacher in Germany with no warning that this was a flashback and not indeed actually happening during that very moment, then Paul gets fired. Surprise, surprise they are now back eating dinner again and Paul continually has these flashbacks with no warning what so ever. At the very end it seems as if the son is actually beating these people to please his dad because when the son does beat these people his dad laughs. That's horrid. I may have somehow missed a deeper meaning behind this book but I would not recommend this book to anyone of any age who liked any particular genre.

Another book I wouldn't have stuck with if it weren't for my book club. I'm actually rather disgusted that I spent money on this...There were no characters I liked or felt I could identify with. The approach of having the entire story take place during a dinner was I suppose an interesting tactic, but not believable given the topic they were there to discuss. Paul's constant sulking and ranting narration did nothing to make me want to pick up the book and keep reading. Stories with moral dilemmas can be very thought provoking, but I didn't actually find this to be challenging so much as nauseating. I felt like it was an attempt to be dark and shocking simply for the sake of being dark and shocking. If you're going to present the reader with a situation which causes them to honestly question whether they would *really* "do the right thing," you've got to present a problem that is at least morally ambiguous due to uncontrollable circumstances. There was nothing ambiguous about the morality (or lack thereof) in this story. And neither could I feel any interest or empathy in any of the characters.Frankly, I thought the characters and their actions were loathsome and I can't think of a point in time while reading this book that I felt anything resembling enjoyment or interest.

I honestly lack all understanding of what this book received so much attention. Once you finally get past the initial 10 chapters consisting of nothing but the narrator complains about his brother you discover that all of the characters were deeply deranged and vapid. Zero real resolution is achieved and the story arc of the adopted child is extremely troubling. The treatment of his murder as a means of covering up the heinous act of the other two children in the family alludes on a very disturbing notion that adopted children are somehow less than important and in this case less than human. The books concludes with all of the characters being extremely satisfied that they have had no consequences for their actions, except for Serge who suffered disfigurement for trying to do the right thing. The moral of this story being that is you are wealthy and powerful enough you should never have to pay for your actions and murdering those who get in your way is totally fine if they are poor, black, vagrant, or otherwise not of your same social class and ethnic background. This book is simultaneously dull, disturbing, and offensive. Honestly I think it is disgraceful that it is on so many must read lists.

How do you say “garbage” in Dutch? A few years ago, I instituted a personal policy to no longer read books authored by cis white men (with the exception of Neil Gaiman because he transcends time, space, gender, & dimension). But, I had put this book on my want to read list 4 years ago and figured I could make an exception just this once as I randomly came across it in the library. Yikes on MFing ableist bikes, what did I just subject my face eyes to? This is, without a doubt, one of the worst books I have ever read. First, blaming the main characters’ issues on what is obviously supposed to be Asperger’s syndrome is beyond the pale. People with autism are not conniving murderers because of a genetic malformation. In fact, they are far more likely to be the recipients of violence rather than the instigators. So maybe we don’t need to promote popular fiction that elevates ableist tropes against an already marginalized population? Second, wouldn’t it be nice if psychopaths acted like monsters 100% of the time? This book helps maintain that fantasy which helps real life abusers to benefit.This book does actual harm.

[spoilers] I was going to give it four (and a half) stars, but I was perplexed as to whether the author had been inspired by any specific condition to characterize the syndrome Paul supposedly suffers from. I vaguely thought of Huntington's, but it was strongly implied that the syndrome was also the cause of Michel's violence, which would not have been the case with Huntington’s (Michel is only fifteen). And then I found out that Koch partly inspired him self of — of all things — Asperger's. What. The. What.To start with the obvious, Asperger's is not detectable in utero. Second, aspies are much more likely to be victims of violence than perpetrators. Third, as the mother of a child who has (what used to be known as) Asperger’s, I find the unchallenged opinion of the psychiatrist that it would be best to have an abortion if you could tell your child had it profoundly repulsive (he lumps in kids with DS too). So while this book is a dark (I like dark) sometimes uproariously funny page-turner, it’s now deeply tainted by my repulsion of the way Kock thinks of autistic people. Hence the one star.

Wow, I really did NOT like this book!! The characters were incredibly unlikeable, pretty much every single one of them. They were spoiled, pretentious and uninteresting. I think a few of them were sociopaths. The story was mind numbingly boring for at least 90 - 95% of the book. I made the mistake of listening to the audiobook and it sounded like even the narrator was bored by the sheer number of times he sighed while narrating. The only time he didn't sound bored was every single time he said the name Serge, because he overdid it so much every time he said that name. I rolled my eyes every single time he said it - I found it very obnoxious. There didn't seem to be any resolution in the book and I felt like I had no idea what was happening at the end, but that could just be because I had tuned out and just couldn't wait for it to be over. This book had been on my TBR list for quite awhile and I really wish I had read some of the Goodreads reviews beforehand and just left it there. I feel like the one star I gave it is generous...would not recommend to anyone.

I knew the basic premise of this book before I began it; two couples were to meet over dinner to discuss an unfortunate happening involving their two sons. A simple plot with great potential that ultimately never came to fruition to me.First off, the prose itself was bland and forgettable. My pen was ready to mark and underline any phrase or paragraph that caught my fancy but never made a scratch on the paper. A lot of the phrasing was incredibly redundant for absolutely no reason. The narrator would reiterate the same few words at the end of a sentence two or three more times by the end with no added effect save annoying me, the reader. The only section of the book where I feel the prose fulfilled the author's intent was the description of the head waiter annoying the narrator with how he presented the food presented at the table.The plot and characters also gave a brief, tantalizing look of intrigue before stumbling over their own lack of morals into a misaligned pile of skulduggery and violence that offered no redeeming qualities. In the beginning, I felt the elder brother, Serge, was to be the villain; he was rich, powerful, and had an air of condescension and unbridled egotism about him as well as a plastic trophy wife on his arm. His younger brother, the narrator, seemed like the sympathetic shadow, continually dwarfed by his titan of a sibling. His wife, Claire, is smart and calm and steadfast in sticking by her humble lovers side. But then everything flops in a very unexpected and unrewarding manner. In fact, every character is ultimately revealed as utterly lacking in morals and the cathartic defeat of one only implies the disappointing success of another.In terms of the plot, there were several details that, while not quite plot holes, made the fabric of the story too slackened for my liking. The narrator is revealed as an incredibly violent man who repeatedly beats people to an inch of their lives (both in private and in public) and faces absolutely no repercussions for it. This is never explained and not even given a lampshade hanging. Similarly, Claire, who at first appeared by far the most normal of the four, turns out to love not the medicated and sedated version of her husband, but the violent, red-blooded, over-eager pugilist of a man and encourages him. Why? Why, living in an upper middle class family with no visible or mentioned woes, would she prefer this monster of a man who, based on his erratic behavior, may turn on her at any moment? While arguably this attraction is true within the fiction of the story, it seemed too far fetched for me to be the unbreakable chain that kept the family together. In addition to this, she follows closely in her husbands footsteps and slashes Serge with a broken wine glass to further her own purposes. Again, no repercussions (Why? What would remaining quiet serve? The only thing it would do would ruin the plot Koch was aiming for, so it is never fully discussed at length). Were they just a loving, ultra violent family? In the society Koch painted, that seems like an inherent contradiction.Then there is the case in point of the two boys who caused the eponymous dinner to take place. Serge's adopted son knows of their crime and blackmails them, but for what? His father is about to become Prime Minister. They all ready have a great amount of money. The boy appears to have everything he could want both materially and emotionally, but immediately feels blackmail is the prime path to take. In addition to this, the boy is shown to be in cahoots with the two boys previous troubles; in flashbacks, he's one of them, being dragged by his ear away from the authorities by whatever hooliganism they've just acted out. The impression is given that he shares a great deal of their mentality (and the two boys, especially Michel, the narrator's son, is shown as having always been a deviant), but is also the first to immediately betray them. Perhaps his lack of morals was greater than theirs, but then why did he not participate in their penultimate crime? That entire subplot and it's incredibly unrewarding resolution (a rather obvious murder that is implied to be unsolved and with no clues) just drags the book down farther.There was nothing satisfying about this book. In the end, all the character's were evil and for no thematic reason other than 'They just are.' I've read books before where the vast majority of the book was composed of evil characters. In fact, my favorite book of all time, Blood Meridian, does this to a greater degree than The Dinner. But the difference is twofold; the first is that there is some fight against the evil (even if it is ultimately useless) and the second is that the evil has a purpose and is representative of some facet of humanity we all share. In 'The Dinner', the closest thing to a redeeming character is Serge, who in the end tucks his tail and runs despite having all the power in his hands, presenting the villains their victory on a silver platter. This is in no way enticing for a reader. There is no existential of nihilistic viewpoint behind it that makes one question the roles of good and evil or the futility of virtue; they are simply villains who win because of the utter incompetence of the only character remotely close to moral. The reason for the narrator's evil in the book is that he is born with a rare disease that causes a mental unbalance. How horribly unfulfilling. it would be like explaining the love of a horribly romantic couple on brain damage instead of the appeal of the characters. Making the story come from this wholly foreign person's eyes only distances myself from my entertainment in the story.The only reason I wouldn't give this book one star out of five is that it did what it tried to accomplish; build suspense and drama in the characters. Unfortunately, Koch chose a suspense and drama I could not care lass about and backed it with a poorly thought out and unbelievable characters in a story that revolved around realism.

HATED THIS BOOK! I almost threw it on the floor but then I remembered that I was reading it on my tablet. There is nothing likable about this book. The characters are a poor excuse of a decent human being, thinking they should be above the law because they are privileged. I'm amazed how more concern the parents were about protecting their family than actually doing the right thing; no remorse, no conscious, no owning up to your actions. To make things worse, I don't understand what the purpose of going out to dinner to discuss a private matter was needed. Private matters should be discussed at home away from the public.... unless you want witnesses. HATED the ending. It made me sick how they were no repercussions and how no one seemed to put two and two together. Ugh! Don't see how this could be a movie since the majority of it takes place at a restaurant while offering flashbacks to one of the parent's past. My advice, skip it unless you can borrow it for free.

I usually don't leave reviews of books, but I fear this is one I'll want to give a second chance to in a couple years if I forget how terrible it was. This book was the biggest eye roll I've ever read. Do people truly think this way? I recognize the need to protect family, especially children, no matter what they've done. But these parents continue to justify in the most absurd and unbelievable ways what their sons had done. The narrator also repeatedly hints at things to get you interested, but then never touches on them. But really all they add is irritation that the narrator thinks he's more intelligent than the reader (which, I can assure you he's not). And the story itself was so disappointing. I could probably write a novella explaining that (which I won't waste my time doing).The book was a very quick read, which is the only reason I finished it (it only took me a couple hours). But honestly, I find it laughable that it receives any praise at all.

I read The Dinner because I thought it was going to be like Gone Girl. It’s NOTHING like Gone Girl. It took me forever to get through this book because I just didn’t care. Most of the book was nonsense and the story didn’t even start until the last 100 pages are so.Once the story FINALLY picked up, I feel like a lot of the writing was a cop-out. The narrator actually refuses to reveal a lot of details about his story, and you never even find out what illness he has. It seems like the author was too lazy to come up with these details, so he simply left them out.I think the icing on the cake was when the brother lost the election because he shaved his beard? Was this supposed to be satire? It’s probably a social commentary about something or other, but by this point the story lost any sense of relevance in my eyes.I was originally going to give this book 2 or maybe even 3 stars, but writing this review has made me so mad that I’m just going to give it 1. What a waste of time.

I can't think of any time I have ever disliked a book as much as I have disliked this one. In an attempt to get the the "unbelievable ending", I pushed myself to keep reading it. I should have known that I wouldn't have liked this book by the fact that Gillian Flynn endorsed it, and it was marketed as "If you loved 'Gone Girl', you'll LOVE 'The Dinner'!". I wouldn't have wasted my time if I had known that every single character in this book was unlikable in every way. In my humble opinion, it shouldn't be too much to ask for at least one character whom you can sympathize with. I felt no sympathy, empathy, or liking toward anyone in this book. It felt like a forced attempt to write something others would find gruesome. The reality is, the things that most people find to truly be despicable are things that they can imagine happening to them or their friends/family in real life. One and a half stars.

OK. I finally made it through this book. I kind of hated it to be honest and it's hard to articulate just why. I think of more enjoyable, but unsettling point of the book, that other readers enjoy is how the narrator (Paul) and his wife (Claire) are slowly revealed to be these morally bankrupt, disgusting people. I did not not find Paul's nastiness about everyone and everything at the start of the novel to refreshing or funny. I felt like I saw him for who he was early on.. It was no surprise to me that at the end that he and Claire turned out to be who they were. At first I found the writing in this book pretentious and annoying to me. I'm not sure, now I've finished it whether this writing is indeed Herman Koch's style or if it was employed on purpose to convey the story and the characters along in the way Koch wanted. Either way--I am certain I will not be reading anything else from this author in the future.

Two couples, two brothers and their wives, are having dinner together in a restaurant to discuss their teenage sons’ unthinkable crime and what to do about it. It has been months since the crime. The discription the younger brother, Paul, gives of what the two boys did the night of the crime was graphic and extremely disturbing. This story’s characters lack a moral compass and exhibit not as much of a moral struggle as I would expect. The only ones who struggled with the situation at all were the older brother, Serge, and his wife but even they were disappointing. Disturbing, unlikeable characters and lack of justice for the victim made this an unsatisfying story. No inspiration, no wisdom, and no renewed belief in humanity for the reader to take away. Certainly this is not a story I want to think about long after reading it.

This is really the worst book I have ever read. I'm really sorry to Herman Koch, because you have written it really beautiful and it definetly wasn't the writing style I didn't like. It was the whole story and how the father deals with the secret his son has been living with. I just hated it. And I especially hated the father and his actions. And then his brother, ugh terrible. But again Herman Koch, my compliments because despite the fact that I hate your book, it is a really good book. I have talked to multiple people about it and everyone has such a clear opinion about it. It is a book where you can litteraly debate over. So for everyone who wants to read it, don't not read it because I hate the book, there are so much people out there who do like the book and it is a good book, I just didn't like the characters.

I wanted to like this book, it's been on my to read list for a long time. Recent reviews about the upcoming movie left me concerned, but as movie and book quality are not always linked, I still went into this one with high hopes. Sadly, I hated it. The narrator, Paul, his wife Claire and son Michel are sociopaths with no sense of guilt for committing violent and in two cases murderous acts. A mystery hereditary condition is supposed to contribute to Paul and Michel's actions. For Claire, she just seems to like them that way. What makes it worse is that the only ones who suffer any lasting consequences are Serge, who loses his looks and career, and Beau, who we are left to assume is murdered by Michel and Rick to cover up their initial killing. Paul and his family seem to be left to continue on and harm others in the future.

Hated this book. I knew from the beginning that I would not like it but I cannot not finish a book. The narration was ridiculous -"I'm not going to say what was wrong with Claire, not here", "so without going into detail about Claire's illness...", it took entirely too long to get to the plot, and the long drawn out descriptions of mundane things like men peeing in the bathroom and descriptions of their food, and the constant mention of the restaurant's manager's pinky all got on my nerves. Really, I cannot understand how this became a movie. Just an awful awful story!edit: reading reviews now and seeing lots of comparisons to Gone Girl, now THAT book I could not finish so it's no wonder I didn't like this book as well yet I finished it :/

This book started out engaging, but it fell off the rails for me once I realized that there is not a single redeemable character in the entire story. They're all just a bunch of psycho, rich, egocentric as*), protecting their psycho offspring. I am more than capable of setting aside my own bias and enjoying a tale on the dark side, but it has to be well written. I found the writing style of this author jarring, the constant reference to places, names and situations in which the narrator would go on and on about but then not want to mention the actual name of the disease or person was infuriating. The ending was so bad and contrived I felt like I got robbed of the time I wasted reading this book.

Bleh! Found this one while going through my Audible backlist, remembered I DNF’d it years ago and decided to give it another shot. Worse than I remembered. Honestly, if there hadn’t been the heavy handed implication that Paul had Aspergers and would have been aborted if he parents had known (I mean, WTF) and that was why he was a sociopath instead of just implying that he was a sociopath/psychopath I would have given it 2-3 star and said it just wasn’t my taste. But that pretty much ruined it for me. Also don’t understand why Serge continued to associate with his brother after he hit him in the face with a frying pan.

Oh my gosh, did I ever hate this book! There wasn't one enjoyable part to it. I wasn't so much bothered by the fact that the characters were completely unlikeable (I've read "Girl on the Train", a likeable character isn't necessary for enjoying a thriller like that); instead, I was bothered by how pathetic and predictable the ending was. I was bothered by how slow and meandering it was; how the writer would take us on long - and I do mean LONG - detours that seemingly lead nowhere. It was just such an odd, uncomfortable book to read. To the so-called "professional" reviewers who heaped endless praise on it … I have to ask all of you: Did we read the same book?

I will be honest, I did not enjoy the book. Though, it really feels more like a play, than a novel. The major dilemma it poses to the readers is unrealistic. As a parent, I would also do anything for my child, but the characters seem to want to justify murder depending on the victim's likeability. The language is pretentious and the storyline gets caught into too many gaps that the author draws attention to, but does not fill. The main voice is that of an angry, violent man, whose actions are disregarded due to a disorder he suffers (?) from. However, kudos to the author's ability to remain true to his characters, as despicable as they may be...

Wow. I was glad I listened to this as an audiobook instead of reading it. At least as an audiobook I could put it on 2x speed. While this is an okay premise, and would have potentially made a great short story, it's FAR too long. The narrator is going through a very worrisome situation, but he's terribly involved with the minutia of everything about the dinner/restaurant to the point that it takes away from the meat of the story. The actual story and characters seemed very shallow... They had backgrounds, but it was extremely stereotypical. Even the attempted approach at addressing mental illness was poorly navigated.

I have read thousands of books but none compare to The Dinner, none come close to the level of ugliness one author can imagine onto the page. The sociopathic narrator, unreliable from the start, is a totally unpleasant mind to live inside throughout the novel. I hated him. Nasty, mean, paranoid, and violent. I wanted to do a cleanse after reading this book. Because we only have this one, sociopathic narrator, we have no idea about the true nature of the other characters which means we have 2-dimensional characterizations.That there are no neurological conditions (or very few, and they don't fit Paul's profile) that can be tested, makes the whole amniocentesis angle not credible. That Paul would still be walking the streets after beating a school principal almost to death is not credible. That Serge would have anything to do with his brother after his brother had beat his head in with a skillet is not credible. That Serge would allow his son to play with Michel after the vacation from hell, is not credible. That Clare would "glass" Serge AT THE RESTAURANT is not credible. This book is manipulative and sensational, cashing in on the era of sociopaths and helicopter parents.And as a reader, I felt manipulated. Of course, having a sociopathic narrator, one is going to feel manipulated. But I felt the author also set up situations, used plot devices that have no basis in reality, to manipulate the reader. Pissed me off. To think that this author actually spent some of his life depicting this excrement of humanity is mind-boggling. I read it because it was a Book Club book. All I can say, after reading it, is that was a day of my life that I will never get back.

This was a serious struggle to get through. I could find very little to relate with in the book and I was left wanting in the entertainment department as well. These characters are horrible with no sense of self or direction or compassion ... all they really did was rationalize horrible behavior (usually their own) and have no remorse for the things they’ve done. I felt like humanity was left outside the restaurant and that ATM booth. So disappointed. I really like works of fiction to grab my attention and take me on a mental or emotional roller coaster. All I really felt was irritation and contempt.

Honestly, this is no writing that warrants the reader to finish. It's written alright enough to keep you interested into what suspense is next. However it never delivers. The shocking part of it is downright screwed up. Thinking this is the major plot point to bring the 2 couples together. Horrible people make horrible kids. That's a good premise for a novel? All assholes. Each character. I kept reading because it was a simple read to hope something actually interesting came along and no it did not. Fuck, at least Gone Girl had some ballsy plot points. Stop saying this is European Gone Girl. Quite honestly this book doesn't deserve the hype it's somehow created.

Omg. I couldn't have hated it more. The satirical element does not convince. By which I mean I can't shake the horrid impression that the author himself isn't sure the despicable characters in his book are really all that despicable. Maybe I'm all wrong. Maybe he's empathetic and intelligent in real life and this really was a (heavy-handed/clumsy) skewering of bourgeois entitlement and family-first egoism. But several factors make me doubt it, including the lazy and irresponsible allusions to Asperger's as a rationale/excuse for sociopathic violence. Ugh. I need something hopeful in tone to counteract this depressing book, something considerate of the reader's intelligence.

I can't with this.All the characters in this book are complete nutters. The setting is unbelievable and I couldn't visualize these adults speaking about the "violent act" that took place, in a crowded restaurant, especially with one of the adults being a well know politician. There are a few things that bother me, but for the sake of not spoiling it, I won't go into further detail. This is just my opinion, but again, I can see why a lot of people would enjoy a story like this. It's the shock and the, "I can't believe it, how could that happen?" feeling we all get sometimes when reading a book. Some execute stories like this better than others, and for me, this wasn't hitting that spot.

So...this book has reviews that are all over the place. You either love it or you hate it. I fell in the latter, I did not like this book. At all. I did not like the characters, the plot, the conflict. The Dinner focuses on just that- one dinner with two couples. Both couples have a 15 year old son and we find out what these two boys did that proceeded this dinner. I thought the actions of everyone involved was gross, the writing was forced, the whole premise dark and twisted. This book was just not for me.

Unfortunately, I did not finish reading The Dinner by Herman Koch. I made it halfway through before losing interest. I found the writing to be rather tedious, and the story dragged on and on. There simply wasn't enough tension or intrigue to keep me interested, and I had no desire to continue reading in order to solve the mystery. Therefore, I gave up reading the book. I waited a long time to write my review in the hope that I would one day want to finish the book, but that never happened and I am now certain I will never finish reading it.

I am not one that takes pleasure bashing a book, so it pains me a bit to admit how much I HATE this novel. I hate the timing of the narration, I hate the shift from present to past, past to present, I hate the unsaid details that the narrator claims were not important or were too personal, I HATE the end, I dislike all of the main characters and I feel like there were too many incomplete story lines built into this piece. I think maybe this story would have worked better either as a short story/novella, or as a lengthier book, but with a new organization and structure.

I want the time of my life back that I wasted reading this book. It wasn't just that the moral compass of every single character is busted - I could have overlooked that. My main complaint is that over half of the book was a flashback (as far as I could tell) and I just did not buy it. The flashback did help with the plot line, but it was totally unnecessary for it to consume that much of the text. In short - save yourself a few hours of reading and see the movie - or don't do either, and your life will be the same.

I originally gave this four stars because I thought it was pretty decent and dark. Then I decided to look up what disorder Paul supposedly had, that was passed to his son, that can be found though testing while pregnant, that can be treated with pills. And now my view on it has changed completely. I won't get into it, you can find it really easily with a simple Google search. I am not a fan of lazy research or, in this case, no research and just writing what you want even if it's completely off base. If you're going to write about a disorder do your damn research and not just write whatever the heck you want.

This book is a disaster. On page 89 exactly is where the book’s plot actually begins. There are only 100/297 pages dedicated to the plot. The other almost 200 pages are weird memories and unrelated thoughts the narrator has about his past and about nonsense. This book was soo horrible I couldn’t even finish it! I am genuinely frustrated I wasted my time on giving this book a shot. Oh man, those glorious ratings on the cover and back are lies. This book’s narrator is also very annoying and plays this victim role throughout the entire book. Just don’t even waste your time.

I didn't like this book at all. It took so much effort to keep reading. All the characters are unlikeable. The narrator is a dick, and his wife and son are extremely unlikeable. The fact that they would have their murderer son kill his cousin to cover up another murder is such crazy logic. The second premeditated and vicious. The incessant pointing out details that are useless and bring nothing to the story and omitting things that will fill in the blanks is infuriating.Glad I've finished this book because it's going back to the library and I never have to read it again.

The book reads a bit too much like a teenager trying to seem cool by being edgy. It deals with mature subjects in an immature and not-previously-considered way, but trying to pass them as new and insightful and somehow better for being controversial.In short, I struggled through it, but couldn't help but feel it thought too highly of itself. And that's before we acknowledge how it tried to normalise subtle racist views and tried to pull in the reader to agree by presenting them as things everyone feels, brought up by one character and agreed by another.

Book club selection. From the beginning, I disliked the narrator’s constant whining. (Even whines about his urine stream...seriously?). As his real character was revealed, I quickly grew to despise him...and every other character in the book. For those who put his characters “issues” down to mental illness: WHAT possible excuse can be assigned to all of the other people in this book? The story was so bizarre and disjointed, I honestly can’t imagine what we will discuss?! Best thing i can say about it—I am done.

This was dreadful. I dont say this about a book very often but I had to force myself to finish this one. The characters were very unlikable and most likely all sociopaths with no empathy for others. Seemed like the only thing they had in common was a willingness to sacrifice another to save face. I am thoroughly disappointed. This book seemed to have rave reviews that led me to shake my head in disbelief and ask if I had been reading the same book as the other people who loved this. Such a bummer.

It isn't just that this is not really my genre. As I started to read this book, I've had an increasingly uneasy feeling all over me. It isn't just that I hated all the characters. It's the way the whole 'incident' is treated by them. As if it's nothing important. Nothing much. The way violence is described as it's something normal and good. I don't know. I finished the book and I felt a sense of relief. Someone wrote in their review that this is - in some way - a 'fascist' book. And I can't but agree with them.

I don’t even know what to say about this book. What I felt was apathy. I just wanted it over; the dinner, the story, all of it. I feel numb cause I don’t condone any of it or understand people like these that do. The other thing is WHY is this considered a Best Seller? It’s garbage!!! I wouldn’t have these characters over for dinner at all. I wouldn’t even be associated with them, period. I don’t get it. Time to find something enjoyable to read to get these characters off my mind and off my palate so to speak.

Just didn’t buy any of it...not the characters, not the plot, not the wickedness. The little stories all left short. It was discipline to finish this book. They offered this in my Bookclub stating it was as controversial as “Let’s talk about Kevin”, but I found it hard to relate...not believable at all. I even looked at the movie trailer, which I thought they might be a more interesting, but they don’t only have terrible reviews too, but it IS very related to the book, even if they say the movie was terrible but the book wasn’t...would comment on the book but would never recommend it.

I absolutely HATED this book. I picked it up because I saw a trailer for a movie based on the book and it sounded interesting. And this turned out to be the worst book I have read this year. I am filled with loathing for each and every character. I kept reading thinking that it would have to get better, and in fact it was worse. I think the worst part of this book is that the one person who wanted to do the right thing was present as a buffoon. No one had a moral compass. No one had any redeeming qualities. I really hope this is not the way society is going...

I kept reading because I was wondering when this book would hold up to the reviews. Absolutely worst translation of a book into English I’ve ever read. Switching between English and American for school related matters. Calling it elementary school, later using A as marks them swooping to the continental numbers. Using football and soccer when as the same term. The whole book just not saying anything, not giving anything a name... not to speak of a parent promoting their child to kill a cousin and cover it up.

What a terrible book. One of the worst books I have ever read. None of the characters were likable and the main event of the book was incredibly disturbing, only to be trumped by the reaction of said event by two of the main characters in the book. A book about the lengths parents will go to to protect their children, but the way it was told left me never wanting to read another book by this author.

Around the World in 80 Books: The Netherlands!Alright, so I went into this book hearing that it compared to Gone Girl. As far as the plot goes, it's nothing alike, however, it IS a dark plot, with basically no likable characters. So I guess there's that similarity. That being said, I do think the book brought up a few interesting questions: how far would you go to protect your family, and how far is ethical? To what extent should children be held accountable for their actions? Etc. In the situation of The Dinner, I felt like there were obvious answers to these questions, and I hated all the characters for not seeing that. However, it did get me thinking about my own life, my own family, and what I would do for them. In summary, I hated everything that happened in this book, and I hated all the characters (Serge somewhat excluded). BUT I enjoyed the moral questions it posed, so two stars for that.EDIT: After thought, I'm taking it to one star. Unlikable characters, and a cruel premise don't really justify more than one star. On a personal note, my father is homeless, and that aspect of the book made me somewhere in between sick to my stomach, and absolutely furious. I get what the author was trying to do, but I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone.

Awful. The story is told from the point of view of Paul, the father. He is not likeable and he unfolds the story in a schizophrenic manner. He jumps around in the story like he has ADHD. The first 20 chapters are totally boring and can probably be skipped without losing anything.
This is an audiobook and the narrator is the best thing, he is a very talented voice actor and was able to portray all the different characters with distinct voices.

I absolutely hated this book. It was overpowered with unnecessary details and I couldn't relate to it or any of its characters in any way. The only thing that I found interesting was the food, but it would make more sense if the story was supposed to be about food since it wasn't even that became irritating after a while.
Not a book I recommend. On my cover, it mentions that it's an unputdownable book, quite the contrary, I would put it down and not pick it up again. Sorry.

I’m so over the unreliable narrator genre. I much prefer when an author can actual put together a reasonable plot line and bring it to an intelligent conclusion, rather than using shock and awe to finish off their book. I knew when I saw that Gillian Flynn (Gone Girl) recommended the book that I should abandon all hope. If you want to read about a psychopathic family, this book is for you. If you want a thought provoking book with any basis in reality, keep looking.

I have to be honest, I didn't finish this book. I didn't want to - the characters we disagreeable and the mood was awful and it seemed like it was just trying to create a bunch of tension with no real story. Then when it got to the point of explaining what their kids did that was so terrible, it just turned my stomach and I had no interest in finding out what the parents decided or what became of the kids. Not my kind of story.

Unfortunately, I couldn't get further than the first 100 pages. I found the characters to be unlikable, especially the main character and it didn't feel like it was getting anywhere. I also feel that most of what I read wasn't necessary to further the story. The synopsis sounded interesting, but I feel that the book had the same issues as Gone Girl and thus wasnt successful in my opinion. I definitely wouldn't recommend this book to anyone.

This is one of the worst books I have ever read. Endless prattling by the narrator about things that have nothing to do with the book, other than to further emphasize what a completely reprehensible person he is. I hated all the characters, a bunch of spoiled, self-centered, entitled jerks. This could easily have been a short story of about 10 pages, since that's all the content of actual story it contained.

This book was in the same vein of Gone Girl or Girl on the Train. I did not like any of the characters and was creeped out by the father and son. The book is about two brothers who have dinner with their wives out at a fancy restaurant. Throughout the dinner the father is recounting the horrific murder that his son and nephew commit against a homeless woman. Dark doesn't begin to describe this book. I honestly wish I hadn't wasted my time on this book. Do not recommend.

I just can’t anymore with this one. Was listening to it on audio and with 4 hours left I just could not do it anymore. I disliked everything about it, heck I listened to commercials on the radio with more enjoyment. Skipped to the end to find out what happened and bagged it. Life’s too short and I have too many other books waiting to spend anymore of my precious time struggling through this one.

I did not like this book at all. Endless, description of memories or events that don’t add anything to the story.It was dragging on for nothing. I skipped many paragraphes because I was getting board. I would not recommend this book. Some say it is in the same style as Gone Girl. Please do not compare this book to a masterpiece like Gone Girl.

Not good. I hated the egotistical main character telling the story. He was an ass, and he agitated me throughout the whole book. The description of the "dinner" bothered me too - so much complaining! Horrible story of covering up a horrid act his son committed. I just didn't enjoy any part of this story.

DNF -- Audiobook and I didn't love the over dramatized way the reader read. The condescending tone in his voice became too much to listen to. That does make me wonder if I would have been able to finish if I had read instead. A quarter of the way in and I could not take another minute of the petty, nonstop, INCESSANT griping and moaning about the narrator's brother.

I quit early because I don’t care to spend my time reading books with cursing and sexual innuendo. However, the premise was interesting and I loved how the whole book was taking place over a single dinner. But I do have to agree with other reviews, the characters and dialogue didn’t seem very believable to me.

This book was so difficult to get through! The entire setting of the novel is at a dinner so I understand that there will be tangents but this was pretty awful. The writing was in stream of consciousness if the main character and so much of the content didn't seem to have anything to do with the story.

I ended up abandoning this book after 100 pages where absolutely nothing happened!

I might give it 2 stars for good writing but I really hated everything about this. I hated the flash backs and I hated everyone in this book. I don't think I've ever encountered a more despicable cast of characters and the only reason I read the whole thing was because it was the choice of my book club.

Yet another book that wildly disappointed me. It is so promising until you realize that all the characters are legitimately awful people. I was really hoping but the end of the book they would all get hit by trucks so these scumbags wouldn't be wandering the Earth by the end (spoiler alert: that doesn't happen).

Awful. Would give it 0 stars if I could.

This was not at all what I was expecting. There was a lot of back story and I felt like I had to slog through it. Then when you finally find out what happened you are so mad and appalled that you really don't want to finish it but you have to to see how the story ends. It drove me nuts, beginning to end.

HATED this book. As a previous reviewer mentioned, in NO circumstance would you discuss such a matter at a nice restaurant--or in public at all! These people were some sociopaths. Not one part of this book was interesting or enjoyable for me. I also particularly disliked that the narrator would talk about something but not mention specifics "because there was no need." Very annoying.

This book left me with an awful feeling. I hated the main character and the subject of the book is very disturbing. After reading and feeling irritated and wondering what the point of the book was, finally around page 100 the story started to become clear. If given the chance again I would have never picked this book up.

I honestly had to stop reading this half way through. It took way to long for the plot to thicken. It rambled on about random things that didn't seem very important to the story and I just don't have the patience. I look forward to the movie though. ( Which is the only reason I picjed up this book in the first place.)

I really did not enjoy this book. I don’t review many things but this one I felt like I had to. I finished it to finish it. I was not engaged in it all and I’m glad I got it on library lain than paid for it. I dd not enjoy the storyline or characters at all. I typically love suspense books but this did not do it for me.

This has to be one of the worst books I have ever read. Absolute boring rubbish. That's the last time I take a book recommendation from a famous author. I quite enjoyed the start of it, but then it tailed off into utter nonsense, with very unlikable characters. I only finished it because I felt it had to improve, but it didn't. That's several hours of my life I will never get back.

Lame psycho thriller kind of book. Its almost like the author, who could write very well, had this story in his head but before it could be formed completely, someone forced him to write this book.
Paul, Claire and Michel are very forgettable characters.

Dear God, please erase all memory of this evil book from my brain. Never have I felt so repugnant after reading a novel. Bereft of morality or humanity, The Dinner is this generation's Clockwork Orange.

I found for there to be very little rememberable about this book. From the characters ,to the POV, the Plot. I don't feel like it flowed well, characters were 'off' for lack of better words. I'm hoping after a bookclub discussion my rating will improve.

Awful! Just about every character in this book, except for the waitstaff at the restaurant, was totally reprehensible. The congressman had a weak moral compass, but the remaining characters had no moral compasses at all. If you want to feel horrible about mankind, read this book.

Worst book ever! If I could give it a 0 I would. The narrator just rambled on and on dragging out the book for far longer than it needed to be. I wish that I would have just given up on it when it took me three tries to get started on it.

This book will leave you with a bad taste in your mouth. Characters devolve to become cartoonishly evil, for no clear reason. Maybe meant to shock but it comes across as dark like a horror movie- campy. Didn't like, wouldn't recommend.
DNF. The book I was reading was so awful, that I lemmed it and picked up this one while I was at work (book store) since I had it at home. Yeah, I just didn't care. So I'm lemming this one too. Ug.
Sorry I listened to hours of this hateful disgusting book. Not one character is redeeming, nor does the plot say anything nice about humanity, sibling rivalry, baseness of people's moral fiber. Junk.

I wish I hadn't wasted my time on this book. Listen to the other reviews and don't waste your time! Unlikable characters, slow moving, jumps around without giving any indication of timeline, and vague sections that don't create mystery--just create confusion.

Don't waste your time!

One of the worst books I've ever read. Not sure why I kept reading. If I could give it it zero stars I would. Horrid people! Not one character I could relate to. The whole story line is bizarre.

Claimed to be the "European Gone Girl", and this could not be farther from the truth. Bad plot lines and no character development... no interesting plot twists or any resolved ending. I kept reading hoping it would get better and it never did. Very disappointed.

All dislikable characters, super-slow plot, lame mental illness 'Aspergers' reference which is infuriating given that violence isn't remotely a part of Autism. I didn't find it thrilling, and I'm a Gillian Flynn fan. I had a hard time getting into the book and finishing it was a slog.

One of the few times I have ever put down a book without finishing it. I only made it about a third of the way through the book before I couldn't take it anymore. None of the characters were likeable, and nothing was happening except a bunch of whining.

I feel dreadful for the trees that were sacrificed to print this book. And now there's a movie. If I were to ever see it, I could only get it from the library, as there is no way I could pay to see this story in film.

I was very disappointed with this book. Every single character is despicable but at first the storyline seemed interesting but by the end I was completely frustrated with this book. The characters are especially what got to me, not one of them had any redeemable qualities. What a waste of time.

Horrid. Hard to relate to characters. I'm not sure if it was lost in translation or what. But do not agree with any of the reviews about terse writing. It certainly could've been edited into a short story. Waste of time.

This book was like trying to eat a meal on a full stomach. There was no point.
Unless you like the first half of a book over describing what people are eating and the ins and outs of a fancy restaurant, I don't recommend this book. By the time it got into the actual story my appetite was gone.

This book is not very good. The narrator was so whiny and only became more and more annoying as the book progressed. I think the author was trying too hard to create a sense of drama- he didn't succeed. Definitely pass on it.

This left me wanting a lot more. There were so many things unfinished and not fully explained. I hate books that do that. I need everything to come full circle so I can feel satisfied and this was just disappointing.

I stopped around page 100 - I just could not get into this book. The dialogue was boring and the book seemed primarily focused on the food. I just didn't like the way it was written nor any of the characters. Not for me.

After the first 60 pages, I couldn't take it anymore. I skimmed the rest of the book. "I won't tell you what I taught" "I won't tell you what disease Claire had". That's not clever, it's annoying. The whole book was full of stuff like that.

The. Worst.

I finished it in a day and no! It wasn't because it was that exciting, but the opposite. I just wanted to get t over with. If there's a Zero rating I'd have given t. Remind me not to ever read a transcribed book again -_-

Unbelievable situations, contrived dialogue, and unlikeable characters you can’t identify with make up a recipe for a relatively short novel feeling way too long.Also: a lot of the press hypes this book as being suspenseful. It’s not. Tense, maybe. Unpleasant, sure. Not suspenseful.

did not get it and i am sure i did not miss anything, the book is awfully unappealing , the characters are unpleasant and the writer ’ s doomed attempts 2 deliberately impress and charm the reader and his useless trials for a more subtle and profound approach for the plot were simply pathetic

I disliked everything about this book....none of the characters were likable, the idea of going to a very public place to discuss something so sensitive isn't plausible to me, the attitudes of the characters about the occurrences are abhorrent, etc etc. Not a book I'd recommend to anyone.

Giving up at 80%. It goes on and on. Kept on reading hoping that it would get back to the main story line and something spectacular would happen. It didn't and I decided I didn't care what was going to happen in the end.

Blah. Did not like this book. Poor and lacklustre storyline with a lot of gaps and misses opportunities to develop an interesting tale and investigation into human psychosis. Did not like a single character. Could have easily missed this one.

This is one of those books that I can tell is well written, but I just don't like it. I have an admittedly personal problem with unreliable narrators and characters I dislike. It did keep me reading to see the conclusion of the plot, which was interesting.

1.5 stars

i couldn't finish this one. it was well written but not my cup of tea.

too wordy perhaps b/c it was a translation.

a bit too dark for my mood. and it also took too long to tell us the secrets. took too long to get where it was going.
This book was over hyped and overrated, the writing is terrible and it was a chore to finish reading it to the end. I will not be watching the movie version.
I liked the writing but the story was terrible. Nothing really gets going until more than half the story is over. Then you realize what’s going in.
The actually writing isn't terrible. The content is awful. The entire story is unrelatable.

1.75The first 2/3 of this book I couldn’t keep my attention. The next 1/3 was a bit more interesting, but still not my favorite. I’m not a huge fan of psychological thrillers apparently.
I had a difficult time getting into this book. The concept of a story taking place over dinner is unique, but I didn’t like the overall storyline.
I can't even finish this one....
Such a waste time reading this book. No page turner at all.

Positively painful to read.
The story that really went nowhere.
Ridiculous plot and got very boring after the crime is revealed. Characters were not relatable at all.
Not the way I saw it going down , very disturbing book. Unbelievable what this family does.
This book shows the worst kind of people in the world. I wouldn't recommend to anyone since the characters are all despicable and there is absolutely no accountability for horrendous actions.
